div1.p: THE DUELLIST.
[PRICE ONE SHILLING AND SIX-PENCE.]
THE DUELLIST, A COMEDY.
AS IT IS ACTED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL IN COVENT GARDEN.
WRITTEN BY W. KENRICK, LL. D.
LONDON : PRINTED FOR T. EVANS, NEAR YORK BUILDINGS, IN THE STRAND.

div1.head: PREFACE
Extract from the PUBLIC ADVERTISER of Monday, November 22, 1773.
div1.p: ON Saturday last, a new comedy, called the Duellist, was performed, for the first time, at Covent-Garden Theatre. Previous to the curtain being drawn up, the following written hand-bill was dispersed about the house.

Mr. Macklin has been pursued by a malicious party to such a pitch of rancour, that at last they have succeeded so far in their cursed designs, as to get him discharged this Theatre, and thereby have deprived him of the means of a livelihood : Therefore if the Public have any spirit, they will not suffer the new play to begin till Mr. Colman promises that Mr. Macklin shall be engaged again.

This hand-bill found its way into the Green-Room, and had a very visible effect on the performers, as was plainly evident from their confusion. The piece was received with great marks of approbation, and given out again for Monday, which was attended with some hissing, but that was greatly overpowered by the general applause of the audience. The overture to Thomas and Sally being attended to with silence, the greatest part of the Author's Friends, quitted the Theatre ; which being taken advantage
of by a party in the gallery, a riot ensued ; and the entertainment was not suffered to go on till another play was given out for Monday.

To the above concise relation of the circumstances attending the representation of the following Comedy (as it is given by one of the most respectable of our diurnal historians) the Author of the Duellist makes no exception or addition. He would be wanting, however, in that respect, which he has ever professed and shewn for the public opinion, did he not endeavour to obviate some objections that have been made to his Piece, and to account, as well as he is able, for the unprecedented severity of its treatment.

As to the author's pretensions to merit in this species of writing, it is not for him to boast, were there cause for boasting. Because, sensible of the necessity of a dramatic writer's making the theatre the constant scene of his observation, he can without mortification admit that an author, whose study is the stage, bids fairer for success on it than another, who, engaged at a distance in more scientific researches, makes its amusements only his occasional relaxation from severer and more laborious pursuits. Not that he is without reason to be flattered with the applause his performance met with in representation ; though, were it otherwise, he should not have the vanity to copy after a Corneille, who, in the preface to his Pertharite, which was universally condemned, avows boldly, that in spite of censure his play was a good one and well written. He would have confidence
enough, however, in imitation of as great a writer of our own country, to declare, with Dryden, that the town "had received with applause, as bad and as uncorrect plays from other men." As a writer by profession, therefore, whose family depends on his industry, he conceives it not only prudential in him to convert his amusements to profit, but that he has a right to expect the theatres should be as open to receive his productions as those of others. It is true, he has not found it so, and is singularly unlucky in having his pieces performed with impartial applause, and then partially banished the stage. He is not ashamed to declare he writes plays not from inclination but from expediency : the object in his view being not dramatic reputation but theatrical emolument ; to which, while he writes no worse than others (which can hardly be) though it should not be allowed he writes better, he presumes he is equally entitled.

To account for his disappointment in the present instance will not be difficult. Some just exceptions may be made to the piece itself : the scene between the lawyers in the fourth act appeared too long ; in deference however to the opinion of Mr. Colman, who thought its effect would depend greatly on the action, it was risked, and is here printed at length.

As to the passage objected to, on account of its supposed indelicacy, it is entirely omitted. The author must do Mr. Colman, also the justice to say, that he constantly excepted against it, and had his
more cautious judgement been attended to, it would have been omitted in the representation.

Another exception has been made to the whole of the representation, on account of the confusion, I might say distress, of some of the performers. But if the circumstances that caused it be attended to, such performers were so far from being the objects of reprehension for playing ill, that it is a wonder they acquitted themselves so well.

To Mr. Macklin the author has nothing, nor ever will have any thing, farther to say, than that he imputes the ill success of this unfortunate comedy wholly to that performer's resentment against the managers, for having discharged him the theatre ; as it was doubtless their duty to do at the requisition of the the majority of an audience. That ill-success, indeed has been imputed to causes, which to admit, would be to cast an injurious reflection on persons, who, the author is well persuaded, by no means deserve it.

It has been said that the gentlemen of the law took offence at the liberties taken with their profession and practice, in the characters and dialogue of Witmore and Nonplus. They must have too much knowledge and good sense, however, to be seriously offended at what was designed as a mere laugh on the stage, or a satire on what the best of them regret as much as their clients, without having it in their power to remedy it.

A club of booksellers and a crew of authors are said to have formed a formidable phalanx of opposition. The writer doubts not the good intentions of both ; he has endeavoured to serve the cause of literature too much, to have the good will of those, who are labouring, by every possible means, to ruin it. What injury either party might do him in the theatre, the author knows not ; but the scribblers have shewn so little discretion in the zeal to abuse him from the press, that he gives them hearty thanks for the service they have undesignedly done him.

With respect to Individuals it has been mistakenly, or perhaps maliciously, propagated that the piece was calculated to ridicule persons or characters, for whom the author has either the greatest respect, or to whom he is an entire stranger. They who read Mr. Fielding's Amelia will see from what source the author has drawn some of the principal characters and incidents. As the rest of the piece is original, the candid must also admit that he has made no greater use of that writer than dramatic authors have ever been allowed to do with novelists, from the practice of Shakespear to that of Mr. Colman.

It has been suggested, that Mr. Garrick had privately planted a party in the house to oppose the performance. This the author cannot believe ; as, having long since declared himself that gentleman's open and avowed enemy, he cannot, after
what has publickly passed between them, think so meanly even of Mr. Garrick as to suppose he would act otherwise than as an enemy equally open and avowed.

It has even been said that the friends of a certain dramatist, whose name the author forbears to mention, as it is disgusting to the remembrance of his friends, were powerful in the opposition. On this head he will only give a little anecdote, as it was related to him by an auditor, who sat in the Boxes.

"During the tumult in the theatre about the repetition of the Duellist, a Lady who asked a thing that had the appearance of a gentleman, what was the reason of it, was answered that "the Man (meaning the author) was obnoxious and therefore his piece must be condemned." "Yes, madam," added a gentleman who sat by, "There are a multitude of animals in this town, to whom the spirit of a MAN is as obnoxious as the person of a WOMAN."—May the author of the Duellist be ever obnoxious to such Critics.

Lastly, it has been urged, that the Author had not friends enough in the house to support the piece. If by this is meant that the piece had not merit enough to make itself friends, it is false, as appears from the above-cited relation. While its friends remained in the house, it was applauded by a great majority ; but, when a considerable number of these went away, and their places were supplied by riotous partizans,
who could not before get into the house and had not seen it, it is no wonder that both the piece and the author should fatally feel the want of friends.

If this want, on the other hand, be imputed to the Author's neglect of introducing people into the theatre, to influence the judgment of the impartial part of the audience in his favour, he takes a pride in having ever paid in this respect a proper deference to the Public ; whom he should think he insulted, had he acted otherwise, and made personal interest to support his pretensions to literary merit.
div1.l: Too proud to beg, too modest to demand,
By merit only would he fall or stand ;
He only asks a fair and candid hearing.
div1.p: This indeed is cruelly denied him, by the interruption of his play ; but he hopes will not be so on a future occasion ; the Author having another piece accepted at the same theatre ; the parts of which being already written out, and the whole ready for rehearsal, he doubts not the Manager will give him an early opportunity of repairing the loss, attending his present disappointment : Indeed he still places so much confidence on the justice and generosity of the Public, as to slatter himself he shall not ultimately suffer by trusting, without party or cabal, to the candour and impartiality of his Auditors.

div1.head: PROLOGUE.
div1.p: And spoken by Mr. SMITH.

sp.l: DEAF to the bar, the pulpit, and the throne.
And aw'd, if aw'd, by ridicule alone,
The Daring Duellist, in captious pride,
Hath long his friend, his king, his God defied.
Thrice happy we, if laughter from the stage
Should cure this frantic folly in the age :
Happy the father, sister, mother, wife,
Who prize a son's, a brother's, husband's life,
Should we dethrone the tyrant, whose caprice
So oft endangers and destroys their peace ;
Whose fell despotic sway doth ev'n enslave
The great, the good, the generous and the brave ;
Nay, arrant cowards, forc'd into a fray,
Now fight, because they fear—to run away,
Our modish heroes, it is true, may bluster,
Take heart of grace, and all their spirits muster,
This peaceful reformation to oppose,
And take, in talk, our author by the nose.—
But, when the comic muse true humour fires,
And zeal the poignant fatirist inspires
Against absurdity to set his wit,
And folly's mark, altho' in mirth, to hit,
There lies more peril in his pointed words,
Than lies, alack, in twenty of their swords!
Encouraged hence, the poet of to night,
Against these angry boys hath dar'd to write ;
For, by the way, it is on you he reckons,
Nature's own cause espousing, as his seconds.
On this presumption doth he take the field,
Hoping to make the stoutest blusterer yield ;
If silent they, who neither love nor fear him,
Consent to sit, and patiently will hear him,
If they do this, he doubts not to disperse
Their present prejudice for carte and tierce;
Their pointless swords to parry with his pen,
And pistol-proof, put down these mighty men!

div3.head: SCENE I. Witmore's Chambers in the Temple.
div3.stage: Mr. WITMORE and Capt. BOOTHBY.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Really, George, your situation is so critical that I am not lawyer enough to advise you. Sir Solomon, your father-in-law, still so inflexible, say you?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: As positiveness and parsimony can make him. It is not above two years since I married ; and, notwithstanding every proper submission on my part, the earnest and repeated solicitations of his daughter, and the warmest intercessions of our friends, he still seems inexorable as ever.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: That's strange! Time generally softens resentments of this kind. But the love of money, and an habitual passion for artificial trifles, extinguish the sparks of natural affection. As I have acquired, however some credit with him, I will try, when he comes to town, how far my influence extends. And yet, Boothby, this may be carrying my friendship for you too far.

sp.speaker: BOOTH,
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: You know he has a niece, who came over some time since from India to finish her education.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I am told he has adopted her for his daughter ; and in her favour, it is supposed, will disinherit my wife.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: In which case, if I should become her husband—

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: You!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I! Why not, if the lady will have me?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: And have you any serious thoughts of Emilia?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Why, really I do think seriously of her sometimes. The month, I spent, during the last vacation at Sir Solomon's country seat, gave me an opportunity of seeing a number of good qualities in her. She is young, it is true ; but that's a fault one may easily put up with in a woman.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, I know little of her.—Sir Solomon and his lady have strictly prohibited her having any intercourse with Mrs. Boothby.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: To reconcile you, therefore, to them now, will be at least a disinterested proof of my regard for you, George.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: It will so, and yet no greater than I expect from it. Your generosity of disposition, Witmore—

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Nay, no compliments between friends.—On what terms are you with your own relation? With Lord Lovemore, and his brother-in-law, General Gantlet?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: On the best, if I may depend on their professions. His Lordship is now exerting his interest to procure me a regiment ; and, as he tells me, with confidence of success.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I am glad of it—Your promotion may have a good effect on Sir Solomon.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: In the mean time, however, the pay of a Captain of foot, Witmore, is so disproportioned to the way of living in this gay town—

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: That you cannot indulge in the pleasures of it.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, hardly subsist very creditably, and pay the court that is necessary to preferment.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: What think you of my laying open your circumstances to the General? He is my client, and I know you are down for something handsome in his will.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Yes, but I am afraid he'll not be prevailed on to part with any thing while he lives.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Well, you must comfort yourself then by reflecting that cannot be long. He is so fond of duelling, that some antagonist or other will soon kill him, or he will come to be hanged for killing his antagonist. He narrowly escaped the last time he killed his man, as he calls it, and yet he's as captious and quarrelsome as ever.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: He is, indeed, unaccountably exceptious. But, here he comes.

div3.stage: Enter General GANTLET.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Well, Barrister, how is it? —What, George Boothby! By the lord, my boy, I am heartily glad to see thee.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I thank you, General. I hope I have the pleasure of seeing you well to-day?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Never better, my dear boy. —I have just had the superlative satisfaction of chastising a scoundrel.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: What tilting again, General?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: A cool thrust only—But 'twas in him—I paid the rascal home. Here—here—Boothby—here I had him— through—fairly through, by the dignity of man!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Not his body, I hope.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: His midriss! that's all!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: You alarm me, General—who—where?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Nay don't concern thyself, my dear boy—The rogue was in luck—a simple persoration, the surgeon called it ; he tells me there is no danger.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I am glad to hear that.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: And pray, General, what was the cause of quarrel? How did your antagonist offend you?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Me! Barrister! He did not offend me. —Give me thy hand, Boothby, I have done thee an injury ; which nothing but the height of friendship in me can excuse, and the most exalted sublimity of it in thee forgive.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: What is all this? How can you have so highly injured me, General? Be how it will, I promise you I forgive you with all my heart.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: I knew thou wast a good-natured lad and would overlook it, or, by the Lord, thou shouldst have taken him our thyself.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: How, General! Have you been taking up a quarrel of mine :—It was obliging in you ; —but I could wish—

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Oh! Sir! it's enough, I understand you, —you are perfectly in the right, I should have been more punctilious. —It was impertinent in me, to be sure. —A friend may be sometimes too officious. —However, Sir, if you are dissatisfied, I am at your service. —Call me out—You can fight—I draw my sword for no man who dares not draw his own.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, but understand me, General. If you have taken up any cause of mine, I am so far from resenting it as an injury, that I think myself obliged to you. You know I am as tenacious of the punctilio as yourself ; and would never be so rude as to take up the cause of a stranger : but among friends it is quite another thing.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Right, boy. When I commanded in Ireland, my doublet was pinked like the flounces of a fine lady's silk petticoat ; and all in the cause of my friends. The man who would not be run through the body for his friend, ought to be kicked out of the world for a scoundrel.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: An heroic sentiment, General. —But who was your antagonist? I hope, for your sake, he's really out of danger.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p:
Nay, the rascal himself, I believe, is hardly worth the care of the surgeon. I should have wiped my contaminated
sword and left him to his fate, but that it would have been too great an honour for him to die by the hands of a gentlemen.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: And yet, General, I am afraid your magnanimity will one day or other betray you into the doing some rascal or other that honour.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Well Sir, and what then? Would you insinuate that a gentleman has not a right to do himself justice by putting to death a scoundrel?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: By the laws, General?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: By the laws of honour, Sir.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, and by the laws of the land too, if he have a mind to be hanged for it, A man may break all the laws in the statute book, if he be disposed to pay the penalties.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: How, Sir? shall not I annihilate a rascal? Do the laws of England afford protection to scoundrels?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: To a great number, noble General : and so do the laws of honour too ; by which the scoundrel has as often the advantage of the man of honour as the man of honour of the scoundrel. Let us suppose, General, that your antagonist's skill or agility had been greater than yours; would that have conferred probity on him or reflected infamy on you?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Infamy on me, Sir!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Excuse me, General, I speak only by way of hypothesis.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Hypothesis! Sir! Rot your hypothesis, Sir. [takes Boothby aside.] Boothby, have you seen the peer to-day.

sp.speaker: BOOTH,
sp.p: Lord Lovemore? No, Sir.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Then you don't know how his affair has ended.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: What affair, General?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: With the fellow, that affronted him last night.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I heard nothing of it.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Come, come along with me, then. I must know how it ended [turning about to Witmore.] Hypothesis! Ha! Mr. Barrister!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: No offence, I hope, General! I think I could put a case in point—

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: A case in point! With the point of honour, Sir? Offence, Sir! Yes Sir, there is offence, Sir. —Come, come along, Boothby. These lawyers of the Inns of Court know nothing of the laws of honour! —Hypothesis, Ha! Mr. Barrister! Come along, Boothby, Hypothesis! Quotha! [Exeunt GAN. and BOOTH.

sp.speaker: WITMORE
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! What a captious mortal! Could he find nobody else to quarrel with, he would certainly take exceptions at himself and tilt with his own shadow! Enter a SERVANT.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: A card from Sir Solomon Bauble, Sir.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I did not know he was in London. [reads the card.] Sir Solomon Bauble's compliments to Mr. Witmore—would be glad to consult him on a family affair, that concerns him nearly. —If this should be Boothby's business now! I wish it may. —Is the messenger gone?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: No, Sir, he is without.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Let me see him. [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE II. An Apartment at Lord Lovemore's.
div3.stage: Enter Lord and Lady LOVEMORE.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p:
Insupportable! is it not enough, my Lord, that I have given scope to your licentiousness, by winking at your gallantries, that you would make me openly countenance
them? Do you think me really so blind as not to see your designs on Mrs. Boothby?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Look you, Madam, while I contribute to your pleasures I expect you will not controul mine.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: My pleasures, as you call them, my Lord, are unexceptionable. I have no amusements but what are common to women of quality.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Nor I any but what are common to men of quality. In a word, Lady Lovemore, we have been too long married to impose any longer on the world, and we ought to know the world too well to impose any longer on ourselves.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: In what? my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: In keeping up the appearance of domestic harmony, which no longer subsists.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Appearances govern the world, my Lord ; and it is they impose on themselves, who will not enjoy the shadow because they have lost the substance.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Then you think we once possessed it.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: I thought we married for love, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: I thought so too : but I believe we were both mistaken.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Because there has been so little lost between us, and yet there seems to be none left.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: The want of love, my Lord, should not banish decency.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: But it should banish jealousy, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Then your Lordship thinks me jealous, and yet you imagine there is as little love left on my side as yours.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: The less the better, as there is no satisfying the surmizes of a suspicious woman.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, you are mistaken. You do it effectually by converting suspicion into certainty. I have learned to support the being an object of private neglect, but I am not quite so meek as to sit down exposed to public contempt.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: You may avoid it, madam, by retiring from public notice. Our house in Gloucestershire is ready to receive you ; and, if you except to the company, I keep, in town, you may keep what company you please in the country. The post-coach shall be ready tomorrow morning, unless Mrs. Boothby makes one of our party to-night.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord, I will see my brother Gantlet before I determine to stay or go.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Your brother Gantlet, madam! Do you mean to intimidate me with your family bully? Let that blusterer interfere, and I will immure you in the country for life.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: The country! And at this time of year! What cruelty? Is it possible your Lordship can be in earnest?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Your Ladyship may put me to the trial, if you dislike the alternative. I leave you a moment to deliberate on the choice. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVEMORE
sp.p:
Barbarous tyrant! He knows, I doat upon living in town, and detest the gloomy solitude of his Gloucestershire dungeon. I will sometime or other be revenged on him for this treatment. My brother's temper indeed is so violent, that, unless things are carried to extremity, his remedy may be worse than the disease. But I will dissemble with this insolent intriguer of mine ; and, if I have art enough, defeat the execution of his designs by counteracting him. —I shall be able to do this the more effectually by staying in town. —Mrs. Boothby is at present, I believe, a woman of honour, and loves her husband ; whom Lord Lovemore is flattering with favours and feeding with promises, in order to effect the seduction of his wife! What traitors
are men! And mine the most insulting of traitors! With what an air of assurance did he in fact confess it. Look you, Madam, while I contribute to your pleasures, I expect you will not controul mine. But, if Boothby and his wife are not two errant idiots, I will controul your pleasures, my fine scheming Lord, even while you think I am contributing to them. —Here, Echo! Bring me pens, ink, and paper.

div3.stage: Enter ECHO.

sp.speaker: ECH.
sp.p: Pens, ink and paper, my Lady?

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: It is plain you heard, Mrs. Pert.

sp.speaker: ECH.
sp.p: Heard Mrs. Pert! my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Wilt thou never leave off that odious trick of repeating one's words?

sp.speaker: ECH.
sp.p: Repeating your words, my Lady?

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Canst thou say nothing, wench, but what I say?

sp.speaker: ECH.
sp.p: Nothing but what you say, my Lady?

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Out of my sight, thou incorrigible wretch.

sp.speaker: ECH.
sp.p: Wretch, my Lady!

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Begone, I say-

sp.speaker: ECH.
sp.p: Gone, my Lady. [Exit ECHO.

div3.stage: Re-enter Lord LOVEMORE.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Well, Madam, have you reflected on my proposal? Do you chuse to reside in town or in the country? in London or Gloucestershire?

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: You know, my Lord, I hate Gloucestershire.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Well, madam, to indulge your inclination for company ; what say you to Somersetshire? To Bath?

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Out of the season, my Lord! I would as willingly go out of the world.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Well, madam, you know the conditions of our residence under the same roof, in town.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Why, look you, my Lord, as I know you may plead precedent among a number of our acquaintance, if I thought you would pay any tolerable regard to appearances, I might compound with you. It may be prudent for a neglected wife to seem easy under the indifference of her husband ; but she must be meek and mean-spirited indeed, if she can submit to be insulted by his mistress. Not that I think you will succeed with Mrs. Boothby. She is, I believe, so fond of her husband, that, I am persuaded, I may safely trust her with you.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Do so then, and be satisfied if I keep up appearances, as you term it. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE,
sp.p: I will, my Lord, and hope to fit you too at the keeping up of appearances. [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE III. An Apartment at Sir Solomon Bauble's.

sp.stage: Enter Sir SOLOMON and Lady BAUBLE.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Pooh, Sir Solomon, what a rout is here about an old rusty counter and a roll of cinder-coloured parchment? I suppose Mrs. Brush has flirted them away in dusting the dining-room. —Mrs. Brush! —

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p:
No, no. My lady! I tell you I have been robbed, plundered! I have lost two curiosities that would have caused the museum at Bauble-hall to be admired by all the antiquaries and connoisseurs in Europe. An Otho, in the highest preservation, and a Greek manuscript dug out of the ruins of Herculaneum!
Enter Mrs. BRUSH. Who has been here, hussey, in my absence this morning?

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Nobody, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Nobody, Sir! But, I say, somebody has been here—somebody must have been here. Where's my antique? my Otho?

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, here has been nobody but Dr. Birdlime and another of the letterati from the Antic-queerian Society.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: And you shew'd these nobodies into the dining-room, did you?

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: As I knew your worship knew one of the gentlemen, Sir, and I thoft the other gentlemen was another gentleman ; and especially as they were both Antic-queerians, I thoft them next kin to nobody. Indeed I thoft no harm, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: You thoft! you thoughtless baggage! who taught you to think? Get you gone about your business!

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: (aside) Here's a fuss indeed about their Othurs and anticks. [Exit BRUSH.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Dr. Birdlime eh! Yes, yes, I knew if ever he came in the way, my medals would stick to his fingers. But if I do not prosecute the pilsering quack with the utmost severity of the law. —Egad, I'll go to Sir John Fielding and take out a warrant to search his house immediately.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p:
Fiddle faddle, Sir Solomon, the copper-smith, who made that Otho, can make another ; and, as for the loss of your manuscript, I'll present your museum with my sentimental journey to Margate ; which Dr. Pompous says is worth all the manuscripts of Herculaneum put together. —But come, Sir Solomon, we have matters to mind of more importance. — I have communicated to your niece Emmeline, the arrival of
her intended husband, Governor Mammon, from India, and bade her prepare to receive him accordingly.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Well, and she was overjoyed at the news! Eh!

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Quite the reverse.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: The family seems doomed, Sir Solomon, to have all its projects frustrated by the perverseness of undutiful children. Your daughter threw herself away on that Captain Boothby, a young fellow not worth a groat, and here is your niece averse truly to marry governor Mammon, a man as rich as a nabob.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: And yet you would have forgiven your daughter, as you will your niece, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: I forgive them, Sir Solomon! I would have you to know that I have a spirit as implacable and unforgiving as yourself.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Poh! Poh! You, foolish women, are easily prevailed on to do any thing. But why my daughter, and my niece? Madam! Why not your daughter and your niece? No such perverseness runs in the blood of the Baubles. They would marry any toy for money.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: I thank you, husband, but, vain as you are, I did not marry you for love. The family of the Trinkets, whence I am descended, never sacrificed their interest to their passions, or indulged indeed any passion but that of interest.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: It is much, wise, that children should not take after their parents.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: You a philosopher, husband, and not know that the commixture of two limpid fluids will sometimes generate opacity. Would you have me account for the irregularities of a lusus naturae, or unravel the tortuosities of a froward imagination.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: No, No. That is a task a little beyond the capacity of a woman.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: The capacity of a woman, Sir! And do you still maintain the preposterous absurdity of superior intellect in man? Does not history afford innumerable instances of equal endowments in women? What were Semiramis, Artemisia, Thomyris, Zenobia, and the no less eminent Arataphila, among the ancients?

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Zounds! What a string have I touched upon? Now will she run over the catalogue of all the cunning gypsies and female fortune-tellers that have plagued the world, from the witch of Endor down to mother Shipton.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: What were Catherine de Medicis, Lucretia, Cornaro, Anna Maria Schurman, and Madam Dacier, among the moderns?

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: All female furies, or petticoated pedants, I dare answer for them.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Nay, among our contemporaries, is not my Lady Betty Comment a second Aristotle? Mrs. Politic another Tacitus? And does not Madam Sweet-wort, the brewer's wife at Redriff, write odes with the pen of a Pindar? —Does not— Enter a SERVANT. How dare you, Sir, come in without knocking at the door?

div3.stage: [turning in a pet, walks towards the back part of the stage.]

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: A reprieve! —A reprieve! —Come, come in, Thomas, my lady is only a little in her female altitudes this morning. What's the matter?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: A letter from Governor Mammon, Sir, —His chairmen have set down two chests in the hall ; a present, they say, to your worship and my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: A present! Eh! Are the Chests heavy, Thomas?

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Very heavy, an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: The more heavy, the more likely to be welcome, Thomas. A chest of guineas might be too light! Give the fellows something to drink, and I'll come to you presently. [Exit SERVANT.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: [returning to the front of the stage.] The capacity of women truly!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Prithee, my Lady, don't let such a trifle disturb you. Governor Mammon is arrived in town, and has sent you a present this morning to put you in a good humour. And I doubt not, when I come to talk to my niece, she will receive him as she ought to do. The Governor, I see, knows how to recommend himself.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: To be sure the superiority of your masculine understanding, Sir Solomon, must prevail on my niece to do any thing. As to the Governor, indeed, it must be owned his oriental manner of making approaches by presents, is a captivating mode of address. But let us see what he has sent us : the letter, I suppose, will inform you.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Ay, let us see, let us see. [Putting on his spectacles.] [He reads.] Governor Mammon presents his compliments to Sir Solomon Bauble and Lady : will take the earliest opportunity of paying them his personal respects, and of claiming his right in their amiable niece. In the mean time, begs Lady Bauble's acceptance of— Very polite and well-worded indeed. [pulls off his spectacles.]

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Acceptance of what, Sir Solomon?

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p:
Ay, let us see, let us see. [Putting on his spectacles.]
[Reads again.] Begs Lady Bauble's acceptance of a chest of ornamental china.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Magnificent, no doubt, and worth my acceptance!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Pish! a parcel of pot-bellied pagods and niddlenoddle mandarins; toys for foolish women, and play-things for children.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Foolish women, again, Sir Solomon! I would have you to know—

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: I do. I do. You have told me of it a thousand times already.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: What have I told you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: That foolish women are prodigiously wise, madam. But pray let us see what the Governor has sent me. [Reads again.] And Sir Solomon's of two curiosities, he hopes not unworthy a place in the museum of so celebrated a virtuoso : the one a manuscript sermon of an Eastern Bramin on the duty of women—to bury themselves with their deceased husbands.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Horrid! Why the importation of oriental manuscripts should be prohibited with popish mass-books.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Yes, wife, if they were likely to make as many converts. But the Bramins will make no proselytes here. Our wanton widows would rather run the risk of killing a second husband than bury themselves with the first.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: What foolish women, Sir Solomon, not to be guided by your wise men of the East!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p:
Ha! What's this? [reads] The other! —Sure my spectacles deceive me! [pulling off his spectacles and wiping them ; then holding up the letter to the light.] No. It is—It is—
The mummy of an Egyptian Princess! Inestimable! Invaluable! A present for a King! Have my niece! He deserves the niece of an Emperor! The mummy of an Egyptian Princess! I shall be the envy of all the virtuosi, the connoscenti, the dilettanti in Europe.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: The old fool! In raptures with an odious mummy! How wonderful the superiority of masculine wisdom! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Nay, don't be jealous, my lady, but I can't contain my transports. I must fly to the presence of her highness, my Egyptian Princess. [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE I. Capt. Boothby's Lodgings at Mrs. Goodwill's.
div3.stage: Mrs. BOOTHBY and Mrs. GOODWILL.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: You surprize me, Mrs. Goodwill! General Gantlet fight a duel about me! For what?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Oh, madam! General Gantlet, they say, will fight a duel about any body and for any thing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Yes! but surely not about any body for nothing! What could be said of me to provoke him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Some young spark, it seems, at the tiltyard, observed that Lord Lovemore was fond of promoting officers that had pretty wives.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: And how did that regard me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Nay, madam, you need not beg a compliment ; but the sarcasm was plainly levelled at the lady of Captain Boothby.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: How impudent is calumny! Detestable standerers! Lord Lovemore, Mrs. Goodwill, is one of the most generous of men.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: They say, indeed, madam, that he is very generous where he takes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Where he takes! What do you mean, Mrs. Goodwill? Do you imagine then his Lordship has any designs on me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Have you no reason to imagine it, then, madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: None in the world! His behaviour to me has been always the most distant and respectful.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: It may not be the less designing for that, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Indeed I have hardly ever seen him but in company with his Lady.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: And that you think the safest, madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Doubtless!

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: There are very condescending wives, among women of rank in this licentious age, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Fie, fie, Mrs. Goodwill, there can be women of no rank so condescending as you would insinuate. — You are too censorious; by much too censorious, Mrs. Goodwill. I beg you will throw out no such injurious intimations against any one in my hearing again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: I am sorry my freedom of speech should offend, madam. [Aside as she goes out] Poor young lady! She knows little of the ways of these wicked times!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Bless me! What strange notions enter into the heads of some people!

div3.stage: Enter Lady LOVEMORE.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Boothby, how do you to day? I was determined to be my own messenger this morning, that no accident might deprive me of your company. You must be of our party to night. A little, private, select party, quite among ourselves. I came on purpose to take no denial.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Your Ladyship is so obliging ; but indeed I' had a pre-engagement.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: I will hear of no pre-engagements. You must come and play a pool at quadrille with the ladies; while my Lord and the Captain are engaged with the gentlemen at whist.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Mr. Boothby, madam, hath solemnly renounced the game.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Rash vows, Mrs. Boothby, you know, are made to be broke. My Lord will overcome his scruples on that score, I warrant you, so that you can have no excuse.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: In that case, my Lady, I will certainly do myself the pleasure to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Nay, you positively must come ; we cannot do without you. You will pardon me, my dear, but I must excuse myself at twenty other places—Nay—you shan't stir— My chair is in the hall. —Adieu, my dear Mrs. Boothby. [Exit ceremoniously. Mrs. BOOTHBY alone. How perfectly well-bred and obliging! How can Mrs. Goodwill think ill of such a woman? Really, these good people who let lodgings are too apt to speak ill of their betters. —And yet, somehow, I don't like the tale she told me about General Gantlet. She has seen much of the world, and appears to be a discerning kind of woman. I know not whether I should altogether slight her hints. They were given too with such an air of significance. There may be more in this business than she has told me ; for why should so silly a speech give such offence to the General?

div3.stage: Re-enter Mrs. GOODWILL.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Bless me, madam! I hope you did not say a word, of what I hinted, to Lady Lovemore : the shortness of her visit alarmed me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: That would have been indiscreet, indeed, Mrs. Goodwill ; as I am convinced, however you may be mistaken in her Ladyship, you meant no ill to me. But pray was that idle saying all that passed, to provoke the General so highly?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Nothing more that I heard ; except that the gentleman added, his Lordship chose to procure preferment for his friends abroad, that he might occasionally pay a charitable visit to their wives at home!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Then it is plain the reflection could not respect me. Captain Boothby is to have a regiment in England ; and he hath solemnly promised I shall go with him, if he be ordered abroad.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Yes, madam, but the promises of a husband sometimes bind as little as those of a lover.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, Mrs. Goodwill, I must hear nothing against my husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: I beg pardon, madam—I have done. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: I will exact, however, another promise from Mr. Boothby, that go where he will I shall accompany him. [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE II. An Antichamber in the House of Governor Mammon.
div3.stage: Enter Sir SOLOMON BAUBLE and MAC TOTUM in the Dress of a Banyan.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Mac Totum, ha! And you are no Indian, you say?

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: No, Sir ; but going to India very young, I learn'd their language, and pass for a native.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: That is, you are a kind of a mock-turtle among them ; ha, Mr. Mac Totum! And so, you are your master's banyan, eh! His interpreter, his secretary, his bookkeeper, his cash-keeper, his secret-keeper, his scrub, his every thing, eh!

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: I see, Sir, to the discharge of all those important trusts, either in person or by the appointment of his honour's other people ; for whose fidelity I am responsible ; such as his dallals and darogas, vakeels and gomastahs, mutseddees, chubdars and soontaburdars, down to his honour's, pykes, peons, and cooleys.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: [Aside] A consequential kind of domestic truly! His dallals and darogas, mutseddees, chubdars, pykes, peons and cooleys. Who, the devil, are all these?

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: They are his honour's agents, brokers, clerks, stewards, wand-bearers, torch-bearers, pedlars, porters and running footmen.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: What a tribe of locusts! Why 'tis a retinue for a Sûbah.

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: And yet his honour, on the country establishment, is at present only the Fowzdàr of a Chúcklah.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: The Fowzdàr of a Chúcklah! A kind of Middlesex justice, if I remember right.

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: On his return to India, indeed, he will probably be made an Omrah.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: An Omrah! What a Lord! Eh! —As to that, he might be made a Lord of here. But why this exhibition of eastern pomposity in London?

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: Sir, his honour makes this display of his Indian splendor, in order to induce the young lady, he is going to marry, to return more willingly with him to Bengal.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Nay, but so much ceremony with friends is troublesome. I could find easier access at St. James's—Is the Monarch of the Brititsh Empire more affable than the Fowzdar of a Chucklah?

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: His honour, Sir, notwithstanding forms, is friendly and familiar. The Durbar, his levee, is by this time assembled, and you shall be ushered into the Huzzoor, the presence, immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: The Durbar! Huzzoor! Presence! Egad, this Fowzdar of a Chucklah takes on him the state of a great Mogul! [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE III.
div3.stage: The Scene opens and discovers Governor Mammon magnificently dressed, and lolling on a superb Sofa—On each Side are ranged Black, Mulattoe and White Servants, in Eastern Habits and tawdry Liveries; some holding Branches of Wax-lights, others Silver Wands, short Silver Staffs, &c. The Levee is composed of Jews, Armenians, Persians and Europeans, variously habited.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Munshy Dives.

sp.speaker: DIVES.
sp.p: Your honour!

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Have you looked at that parcel of diamonds? what will you give?

sp.speaker: DIVES.
sp.p: Thirty thousand pounds, your honour! They are large, but some of them are flawed and cloudy.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: They cost me, three lacks of rupees : for two thousand more they are yours.

sp.speaker: DIVES.
sp.p: Your honour shall have the monies.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: The emeralds, pearls and rubies. What say you to them?

sp.speaker: DIVES.
sp.p: Ten thousand, your honour. I would not give more to my own brother.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Transfer, receive and vest the cash in the funds.

sp.speaker: TRANSFER.
sp.p: India stock, your honour?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: What, man, are you mad? —South Sea— And when a snug bargain of terra firma offers, turn it into dirt—Land is a more valuable commodity than paper. — Lazarus!

sp.speaker: LAZ.
sp.p: Your honour!

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Those chests of tea and raw silk—Are they safely run and disposed of?

sp.speaker: LAZ.
sp.p: At your honour's own price.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: And the piece-goods, the cossaes, cushtaes, callipaties, carridaries, doosooties, jamdannies, mulmuls and moosooroos!

sp.speaker: LAZ.
sp.p: All, your honour. —

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Place the money in the Bank. Their paper is as good as cash. —Pandar!

sp.speaker: PANDAR.
sp.p: Your honour!

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: In making provision for my Zenana, let me have no more brunettas. I would not give an anna for your dark-eyed moppetts. But, pay the mother of the fair wench I brought from Plymouth, a thousand rupees, and settle upon the daughter a jaghire, at the rate of three hundred per month, during pleasure. I shall not need your service again perhaps this month. —I am going to be married.

div3.stage: Enter Sir SOLOMON BAUBLE introduced by MAC TOTUM.

sp.speaker: MAC T.
sp.p: Sir Solomon Bauble, your honour! [Governor Mammon rises from the sofa and comes forward to embrace Sir Solomon, mean while the levee and servants go off.]

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Sir Solomon Bauble, I am proud to embrace you.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: And I to return the compliment, Governor— Your Egyptian Princess—

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Is a diamond of the first ; water, you would say ; I knew her highness would charm you.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: She has indeed, Governor ; and has captivated the hearts too of half a score connoisseurs of my acquaintance already. I wish some of the rakish young dogs, among our virtuosi, don't ravish her from me. They plundered my cabinet of an inestimable Otho no longer ago than this very morning.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: I will supply its place, by the next ships, with an illegible coin of the Emperor Ting, Ving, Ching ; who reigned in China, ten thousand years, before the creation.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: You are very good, Governor. And if you could but procure me the genealogy of the Princess—a mummy without a genealogy is like a Welch woman without a pedigree.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Faith, Sir Solomon, I can say little to that. I had her from a Bashaw of three tails, at Mocho, in the Straits of Babel-mandel. If you want to know more of her, we must send to Mocho for information.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Egad, I shall be infinitely obliged to you, Governor. From a Bashaw of three tails, at Mocho, in the Straits of Babel-mandel! Why, she may be one of the daughters of King Pharoah, that was drowned in the Red Sea ; who knows?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: I can say nothing to the contrary, Sir Solomon— But to business—How does my contracted spouse, your niece Emilia ; I intend to-morrow morning to pay my respects to her.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: You will do her honour.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Mean time, Sir Solomon, you will order the lawyers to adjust the necessary preliminaries to our wedding. I have spoken to Mr. Serjeant Nonplus, who will meet your Counsel about the marriage settlements. You will excuse me at present ; I must attend the General Court. —What ho! without—my palanqueen there! [calls to his servants without ; whence is repeatedly heard "His honour's chair."] [Speaking to Sir Salomon.] Nay, no ceremony, good Sir Solomon—We'll go together. [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE IV. Lord Lovemore's.
div3.stage: Enter Lord LOVEMORE and General GANTLET meeting.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Good-morrow, General.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: Good day, my Lord, I am heartily glad to see you—What, it is all over, I suppose—How did the fellow behave?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Over! what should be over, General?

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: Why, did not you call him out?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Him! whom?

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: The rascal that affronted you last night at the whist table.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: I took no affront, General ; nor recollect any that was given me.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: No affront! Did not your partner tread on your toe the moment you were cut in!

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: As we changed seats—An accident! He begged my pardon.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: An accident! Ha! did he not revoke in play?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Misplay'd a spade, I think—An oversight!

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: An oversight! Did he not look askew at you all the evening?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: The gentleman, General, had the misfortune to have a cast in his eye.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: A cast! The misfortune! Eh! I would have cast him into the pit of perdition, had he so squinted at me— A cast! lookye, my Lord, if you think such things to be put up with, it is no business of mine. My dignity will not suffer by it ; tho' my affinity to your Lordship, makes me solicitous for the preservation of your honour.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: I am obliged to you, General ; but I am not so captious as to regard such trifles in a serious light.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: Mighty well, my Lord! mighty well! Captious! Ha! Yes my Lord, I am captious and exceptious too, and you may think me capricious too, if your Lordship pleases; no matter, but while I have the honour to be your Lordship's brother-in-law, and have the character of a soldier to maintain, I will be tenacious too ; tenacious of the dignity of human nature, my Lord. And I say again, if any rascal breathing had squinted at me as that fellow did last night at your Lordship, I would have tumbled him down the precipice of perdition! —And so Lord Lovemore, I bid your Lordship good day [turning round on his heel and strutting off the stage.]

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: [returning] I would my Lord, by all that is great in man [again turning round on his hecl and strutting off ; His Lordship looking after him with a sarcastical smile.]

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: [again returning] You may smile, my Lord ; but I would have crumbled his soul to powder—to atoms, my Lord—to atoms—to atoms [shaking his cane and stalking magisterially off the stage.]

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! If this madman's disposition were not so mischievous, it would be really entertaining. It is to be hoped, however, his phrenzy is of that kind it will soon work its own cure.

div3.stage: Enter SERVANT.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: Captain Boothby, my Lord.

div3.stage: Enter BOOTHBY.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Did you meet the General, Boothby?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I came with him, my Lord, but, supposing he had business with your Lordship, I waited below till he retired.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: What can have possessed him, to day?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: What always possesses him, my Lord. A spirit of contradiction.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: He would bring me into a quarrel here I know nothing of.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: He has been taking up a business too, he says, of mine. But I neither know what it is, nor can I get it out of him.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Then let him keep it to himself. The only good quality he has, is that of sometimes keeping secret his own mischief—How does Mrs. Boothby to day? You spend the evening with us.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Lady Lovemore will have company.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: A private party only ; we shall not play high.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Your Lordship is so obliging then as to pay attention to my finances.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Faith I beg your pardon, Boothby, for the expression ; such attention is unnecessary. I have as good as settled your preferment to-day. There will be soon a general promotion, and you are to have the regiment at Gibraltar.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: You gave me hopes, my Lord, of being provided for in England.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: I did so ; but so many difficulties stood in the way, that, to prevent delays, I acquiesced, You will be recalled home in a year or two at most, so that it is much the same thing as if you were not to go.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I know not that, my Lord. In the predicament I stand with my father-in-law, my absence, in the mean time, may prove prejudicial to my interest.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p:
I can't see that—Mrs. Boothby will remain in England ; and perhaps effect a reconciliation the sooner without you. I shall be ready to do her any services in my
power ; and, if she even chuses a domestic protection, Lady Lovemore will, I am sure, be happy in so agreeable a companion.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Your Lordship's friendship is so generously imposing, that I shall submit my conduct entirely to you, if I can prevail on Mrs. Boothby to acquit me of the promise I have made, to take her with me should I be ordered abroad.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Oh! she is too reasonable a woman to insist on it. A wife, Boothby, is a very troublesome mess-mate, on ship-board and in a garrison. But you will have time enough to reconcile her to so short an absence before you embark.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I shall, my Lord, but I cannot acquaint her too soon with the success of your Lordship's negotiation. I therefore humbly take my leave. Your Lordship's obedient. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Your servant, Captain. —The wife of this Boothby must at any rate be mine. She is a charming woman. But they say she is virtuous and loves her husband. What a villain then am I to go about to seduce her? Yet why that question! I may not succeed ; and mere intentional crimes are venial. I'll risk the trial. By providing for the husband, I secure an interest in the gratitude of the wife. Her affection for him shall plead for the love of her gallant. But, till it works effect, I must be distant and reserved—It were as impolitic to alarm the modesty of a woman, till some impression be made on her heart, as for a General to give the signal to storm till he had effected a breach— [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE I. An Apartment at Sir Solomon Bauble's.
div3.stage: Enter WITMORE and EMILIA.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Almost a week in London, Emilia, and not let me hear from you! Not a line, or a message, to advise me of your arrival!

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: If you knew, Sir, the reason of my coming to town, you would excuse me. I have given you, perhaps, too much encouragement already.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Too much encouragement, Emilia!

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: A young woman in my situation, Sir, should have been more reserved. You know the business, I suppose, on which Sir Solomon has sent for you?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Not particularly. Some law business, I find. I wish, my dear Emilia, you would give me leave to talk to him on a more interesting subject.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: What subject, Sir?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Can you be at a loss to guess, after the many kind assurances, you have flattered me with, of a partiality for me?

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: I hardly know what I have flattered you with, Mr. Witmore. But, whatever was my partiality for you, you should have known that, a girl at my age had it not in her power to give herself away without the consent of her relations.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p:
Give me but your consent to make openly my addresses, and I will do it immediately. Sir Solomon, I know, regards nothing so much as money. But, though at present my fortune is not very considerable, yet my connections and
expectations are such, that I make no doubt of obtaining his consent.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: For heaven's sake, hush, I hear him hobbling down stairs. I have said enough to pave the way. —You will soon know more than I have confidence to tell you. — [Exit.

div3.stage: Enter Sir SOLOMON BAUBLE.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: So, Mr. Witmore, you have been chatting with my niece Emmeline. She's a fine girl grown ; is not she? shot up like an arrow! And I dare say you think her fit for a husband.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: If she thinks so herself, Sir Solomon. Miss Emmeline is indeed grown a fine woman, and I doubt not would make an excellent wife.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: You think so, eh! Witmore! Why to come to the point, then, it was on that subject I sent to talk with you.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: You do me an honour, Sir Solomon, so young a lawyer is seldom thought entitled to. [aside] What will this lead to? Surely she has not broke the ice herself?

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Why truly I have so good an opinion of you, Mr. Witmore, that I fixed my eye upon you as the most proper person I could think of. —I have been greatly obliged both to your talents and integrity.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: [aside] 'Tis certainly so—she said she had paved the way for me— [to Sir Solomon] Your partiality, Sir Solomon, over-rates my desert.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Not at all—not at all. —I have heard the highest commendations of you from the gentlemen of your own profession ; which is a good sign ; a very good sign, let me tell you, Mr. Witmore. You are, to be sure, not yet at the head of it, but you are a young man, and in time will rise perhaps to be Lord Chancellor—who knows?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I am highly indebted to your good opinion of me, Sir Solomon.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Not a whit—not a whit—I declare again I should not be ashamed, were I the first baronet in the kingdom (which I am not by a great many.) I—

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: You transport me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Nay, I protest, had I fifty nieces—

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Oh! Sir Solomon—

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: You should draw up the marriage articles for every one of them, Mr. Witmore.

sp.speaker: WIT
sp.p: Sir! [turning away with marks of surprize and disappointment.]

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Sir! hey dey! why what's the matter, Barrister? Is not the job worth your acceptance? I thought you would have seen to the making your friend Emilia's jointure secure, though you had done it without a fee.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: [confusedly.] Jointure! fee! Sir Solomon! To be sure I have a friendship for the young lady—but—hath she made choice of a husband?

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: She! poor young thing! How should she know how to make choice of a husband? Oh! no. That trouble was taken off her hands some time ago. Her friends in India took care of that—Governor Mammon, who came over by the last ships, contracted two years ago to marry her, on his arrival in England, under the penalty of a lack of rupees; near twelve thousand pounds sterling. So that, you see, we have long had the husband safe enough. We have now only to secure her dowry and pin-money.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: And the young lady abides by this same contract, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: I'll warrant her. Do you know, Sir, Governor Mammon is a nabob?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: [aside] Then every woman is a jilt. [To Sir Sol.] Pardon me, Sir Solomon, I am taken suddenly with a kind of vertigo ; the effect of setting up over a difficult case last night.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Ah! the law! the law is a vertiginous kind of study. But come, sit you down, sit you down. Lady Bauble is not stirring yet, but Emmy shall give you a cordial. —I shall be back by the time you are recovered and have composed yourself— [aside] mean time I'll go take one peep at her highness this morning. Here, who waits there? Where is Emmy? Emmy shall bring you a cordial, Mr. Witmore. [Exit.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Why, what a fool have I been to be made thus the dupe of a child! a chit! a girl! —

div3.stage: Enter EMILIA.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: [running with looks of great concern] Bless me, Mr. Witmore, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Matter! Miss! I am too much ashamed to tell you ; and yet I know not whether I ought to blush most for myself or you.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: Cruel Mr. Witmore! Then you know my situation and have no pity for me. Would to Heaven I had never seen you!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: How can you justify yourself, madam?

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: I don't pretend to it, Sir. I confess I have been to blame ; but I hardly knew the force, or reflected on the consequences of the contract I had signed, till you had taken advantage of my youth and inexperience, to rob me of a heart which I ought to have preserved to give, where, they say, I must give my hand. If you love me as you have pretended, therefore, you will devise some method of delivering me from the bondage, to which the will of arbitrary and mercenary parents (for so I must call them) have destined me.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: And does my Emmeline, then, wish to be freed from her contract with Governor Mammon?

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: I detest, abhor the proposed union. If therefore you can contrive any means to protract or prevent it, you may depend on the concurrence of your Emmeline.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: My Emmeline! Charming girl! thou shalt then still be mine. [He runs to embrace her.

div3.stage: Enter Sir SOLOMON.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Heyday! This is friendly indeed! What! —

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: [softly to Emm.] Sir Solomon! [aloud] Miss Emmeline, I wish you joy of so happy an event, and will certainly take care the covenants shall be as binding as law can make them. [They part ceremoniously.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: [aside] O ho! is that all? Egad my mind began to misgive me. [to Emm.] Ay, Emmy, Mr. Witmore takes part in our happiness, and will therefore take care of our interest.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: I then shall leave my concerns entirely with him, Sir ; but must beg he will take sufficient time, to make every thing secure ; and proceed in nothing with precipitation. [Exit.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: You shall be obliged, madam ; even to the minutest punctilio of procrastination.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Oh! no, Sir! No procrastination! I have given my word of honour to the Governor, that the lawyers shall dispatch their business without delay.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: That's impossible, Sir. A lawyer's dispatch always admits of delay.

div3.stage: Enter Lady BAUBLE.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: What is that, Sir, you talk of delay? I beg nothing may be deferred, on any account whatever.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: There shall be no more delay than is necessary, madam. But a little procrastination is always usual on occasions of this kind ; it looks like a regard for decorum on the part of the lady.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: We must dispense a little with decorum, Sir. The Governor must be complimented with a short day. After such handsome presents! A most superb set of ornamental china!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: True wife ; and the mummy of an Egyptian Princess! —No, no procrastination.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: I think not : where's my niece? Wo'nt matrimony go down with her without procrastination? Leave her to me, Sir Solomon—woman's wit in these cases may do more than man's wisdom—And do you, Mr. Witmore, consult with Serjeant Nonplus, the Governor's counsel, and come both hither for more particular instructions immediately : do the business as securely as possible ; and no procrastination I beg of you. [Exit.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I will obey you, madam. I shall just step into Westminster-Hall, to speak to Serjeant Nonplus; and we will call upon you presently. Sir Solomon, your servant. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: [in a kind of reverie] Your fervant, Sir—your servant—Ha! gone! Odso, what a pity I let the barrister go, without introducing him to the Princess. [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE II. Capt. Boothby's Lodgings at Mrs. Goodwill's.
div3.stage: Enter Mrs. BOOTHBY and Mrs. GOODWILL.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: I could, indeed, tell you such stories of Lord Lovemore, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p:
I am sufficiently shocked at what I have heard already. —Indeed I beg your pardon, Mrs. Goodwill. I yesterday thought you too censorious : but, after his Lordship's unguarded behaviour at his own house last night, I can
believe the worst of him ; and indeed have not the best opinion of his Lady. Would you believe it, Mrs. Goodwill, he had the confidence to make down-right love to me, —to rail at Mr. Boothby, and even offer me his protection, in the very presence of his wife. I find too that Mr. Boothby is to be promoted to the command of a regiment abroad.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: And have you told the Captain your suspicions, madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: I would not have him know them for the world. The consequences would be fatal. But what shall I do? We are under an engagement to go to the masquerade to night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: To the masquerade, madam! Indeed it requires consideration. Strange doings have been carried on at masquerades.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Strange doings, Mrs. Goodwill! You terrify me! —It is an entertainment I have the greatest curiosity to be present at. But if there be any danger attending it, I protest, I will stay at home.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: That resolution, madam, may perhaps too much alarm Captain Boothby.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: That's true, and yet—But here they both come—I am so chagrined and perplexed, I know not what to do—Come, come and sit with me awhile. —You must advise me— [Exeunt.

div3.stage: Enter Lord LOVEMORE and BOOTHBY.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: A fit of the spleen, my Lord! Mere vapours! It went off immediately on her coming into the air.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: I am glad to hear that— [aside] A good omen! she has not yet told her husband I sind— [to Boothby] Why you were both the favourites of fortune. I thought no lady had the spleen while she was winning at cards.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Mrs. Boothby has delicate nerves, my Lord ; and is little used to late hours and the card table. Your Lordship may have your revenge, however, at any time on me.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: I intend to have it on both, I assure you.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: With all my heart, my Lord, when and where you please.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: To morrow night then—to night you know we go to the masquerade.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Be it so—

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: [affecting a langh] Ha! ha! ha! Faith Boothby, thou art the happiest fellow in the world—You have an angel of a woman for your wife. And so she did not tell you the reason of her breaking away so suddenly last night. I must let you into the secret, lest through mistake she think hardly of me.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Why so, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: You must know, that to get rid of the effusions of her gratitude, which she took an opportunity to pour out on me, for the trouble I have taken to solicit your preferment, I, in raillery made love to her, by telling her how easily she might get rid of the obligation.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: And she took you to be in earnest. Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Even so ; but it was in the presence of Lady Lovemore, so that 'twas impossible I could mean any thing, you know.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I am very sure you did not— You will excuse Mrs. Boothby.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Nay, you must make my excuse to her. She left us so abruptly, that she gave me no time to come to an explanation.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Will you apologize for yourself, my Lord? Mrs. Boothby is within.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: No, no, it will come better from you. I must away to the Secretary at war. To tell you the truth, I heard yesterday of a vacancy at home, that may be worth your acceptance ; and therefore desired an interview with him to day. If I succeed in your behalf, you shall know what it is. If it be already disposed of (for there are innumerable solicitants) we will think of it as a gem long lost, and watch the next opportunity of meeting with its fellow.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I am infinitely indebted to your Lordship, for this obliging attention to my interest.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: I only wish I may be able to serve you as I intend—But I must go—Mean time, do you hear, Boothby, make my peace with your wife before I see her again. [Exit.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I will, my Lord—How noble and generous is it in his Lordship to give himself all this trouble of application for me! —And yet—when I reflect on Mrs. Boothby's behaviour last night, and this whimsical tale of a love story. —I don't half like it. His Lordship is a man of intrigue, and the liberties which men of rank think themselves authorized to take, in this age of gallantry, with their inferiors, are alarming. I must speak to Mrs. Boothby. But she'll not be open enough to tell me, if there should be any thing in it, left it should breed a quarrel. —Phoo! hang it, it cannot be neither —in the presence of his own wife! And she one of the best and most amiable women in the universe! I am ashamed of the suspicion. —It is to the last degree injurious to so generous, so disinterested a friend. What a mean contracted heart is this of mine! I blush to think I am possessed of such a narrow soul!

div3.stage: Enter SERVANT introducing General GANTLET.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: General Gantlet, Sir. [Servant retires.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Good morrow, General.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Good morrow, Boothby—You come off winner last night.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Unaccountably so. A novice among adepts and yet so fortunate.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Adepts! Sharpers!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: What mean you, General!

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: The stranger in blue and gold gave you the game every time.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: That was very obliging in a stranger, General. But I know no reason for it.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Then I would make him give one. —Colonel Basto assures me he has seen him at Bath, and knows him to be a common gambler. Lord Lovemore should be called to account for introducing such a scoundrel into company at his own house. —You know, in regard to my sister, it would look ill in me, or else—But I'll carry him a civil message for you.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: To Lord Lovemore! My best friend! impossible to think of it, General. He must have been imposed on, in the character of the gentleman. Or, if not, gamblers now get into the company of the first people in the kingdom.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Not in private parties, at their own houses, Sir. — However, you may do as you please—You may put up with it—But if any other person had introduced a fellow that bad taken the liberty to put his money into my pocket—

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay but consider, General, Lord Lovemore is my friend, my patron, and no very distant relation ; a man of high rank, and your brother-in-law—

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Were he the first Duke in the land, brother-in-law to any body but myself, Sir, here, here [holding open his fingers.] would I pillory his nose—He should breathe through these fingers, Sir, and breathe his last.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: [aside] I must give into the humour of this Goth ; or he may work himself to attack my Lord himself. [to Gen. Gantlet] Well then, General, to oblige you—

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Oblige me! Sir▪ Oblige yourself! support your own dignity, Mr. Boothby.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I Will, General, and call his Lordship to account on the subject of last night, depend on it.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Do my boy, that's a brave lad. Ever while you live, Boothby, support your own dignity. [Exit strutting magisterially off the stage.

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. BOOTHBY at the oppsite door in a fright.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Bless me, Mr. Boothby, what is it you have promised that savage General? What is it he has been advising you? Challenge Lord Lovemore! indeed, my dear, there, was nothing in the foolish affair of last night that should excite such resentment. It was a capricious mistake of my own. He could not mean any thing—Lady Lovemore herself was by and heard every word that was said.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I know it, my dear. But why are you so much alarmed? The General is not in his dignity-stilts this morning upon your account.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Not on my account.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: He took umbrage, it seems, at losing his money last night, and would set every body quarrelling that was concerned in winning it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: [aside] How have my curiosity and impatience betrayed me!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, child, never mind it. You have only betrayed a little secret that I knew before. But why will you keep such foolish secrets from me? A woman should have no confidant in these matters but her husband. Lord Lovemore is much mord open and ingenuous. He has confided in me already, and has been just now telling the whole story.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: [aside] Specious deceiver! but I dare not expose him.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Indeed, my dear, if your error did not proceed from an amiable cause, in which I am so deeply interested, I should think you greatly to blame. His Lordship is so noble, so generous a friend, that I would not disoblige him for the world. Even common gratitude should induce us to put the most favourable construction on his behaviour. Would you believe that he is now gone to the Secretary at War, of his own accord, to solicit a post for me, which he hears is become vacant at home? He seems to take a concern in my interest as if it were his own.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: [aside] Artful villain! I can no longer bear it. [Exit bursting into tears.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Tears of gratitude! susceptible creature! how will she reproach herself now, for having harboured an unjust suspicion of our best benefactor! Enter Lady LOVEMORE. Lady Lovemore! —What nobody waiting there?

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Nay, no ceremony, Sir. I came in without it, because I would not disturb Mrs. Boothby. I hope her last night's indisposition is attended with no ill consequences.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Your ladyship's solicitude is obliging. None at all, it appears to have been a mere capricio, as insignificant as the innocent cause of it.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: As the cause of it, Mr. Boothby!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Yes, madam, my Lord has been here this morning, and has related to me the whole circumstance.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: [affecting to laugh.] He! he! he! and was there ever any thing so ridiculous? You may think yourself a happy man, Mr. Boothby, in so good a wife ; but, I protest, if every married woman were as exceptious as Mrs. Boothby, there would be no keeping up conversation between people of fashion of different sexes, an hour together.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Your ladyship is perfectly in the right. Mrs. Boothby's behaviour was certainly too exceptious.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Oh! preposterous! we must rally her out of this rustic prudery, or she will be fit to keep company with nobody but yourself, Mr. Boothby. I must go and give her a lecture ; indeed I must teach her to think and act a little more like folks of this world. [Exit.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: How easy, spirited, and engaging! Well, after all, though virtue be a jewel, it is like a diamond, which, of the first water, must yet be polished before it displays its lustre. How admirable is the behaviour of this Lady Lovemore! Mrs. Boothby has not less natural goodness of heart, or of native beauty ; but to how much more advantage would they appear if she had her ladyship's artificial habit of displaying them. She will profit, I dare say, by so striking an example. Indeed my wife is as fortunate in having acquired the friendship of Lady Lovemore, as I am in that of his Lordship! [Exit.

div3.head: SCENE III. Sir Solomon Bauble's.
div3.stage: Enter Serjeant NONPLUS and Mr. WITMORE. —The Serjeant dressed in his gown and coif.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: An independent fortune when of age, and great expectations! say you, master Witmore? a lucky hit for a young fellow that has been no longer at the bar!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: With your assistance, Mr, Serjeant, I hope it will prove so.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Why, lookye, brother Witmore, Governor Mammon may be a good client ; so that, should it afterwards come out that I assisted you in this business—

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I will then sacrifice the first good client, I have, to you, Mr. Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: I expect no less than that stroke of friendship— one good turn, you know—

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Deserves another, Mr. Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Nay, if by marrying, the young Lady you make your fortune and retire from the bar, you may give me all your interest too.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I'll do it, Mr. Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Yes, but I will have no hand in any thing but delay. There is no disrepute in the law's delay. I would not do any thing disreputable for the world. It will hurt me in my practice, master Witmore.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Disrepute and dishonesty, Mr. Serjeant, as you shrewdly hint, are two things. Our practice does not depend on our integrity, but on our reputation for it.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: A just distinction! True, character, character is all. You may do what you will if you be but artful or lucky enough to preserve your character.

sp.speaker: WIT.
