sp.p: And if that be neglected, or unluckily lost, be as honest as one will, it will signify nothing.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Egad, Mr. Witmore, for a young man, you seem to know a good deal of the world. It is almost a pity the bar should lose so promising a casuist. You would make a figure at nisi prius and pleas of the crown.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: You flatter me, Mr. Serjeant. But young adventurers at the bar, like soldiers of fortune in arms, should lose no fair opportunity of advancing themselves out of the line of their profession.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Egad that's true—a fortune's a fortune : no matter how we come by it, as our old friend Horace says, Rem facias. Rem—quocunque modo Rem.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Ay, Mr. Serjeant, that Rem is the thing—but I see the young lady coming this way. —If you will just walk into that room, I'll be with you presently.

div3.stage: [Exit Serjeant.
Enter EMILIA.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Witmore, I have considered of your scheme. But I am afraid I shall not be able to set governor Mammon so much against me as to make him refuse to fulfill the contract.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Well, at the worst, he cannot compell you to fulfil it. It is an adjudged case, that the marriage-contract of a minor is not binding. But never fear! play but your part with discretion, my dear Emily, and you cannot fail to deter him from the match. Repel his first attacks with vivacity and you shall find me, and Serjeant Nonplus, who is within, ready to compleat his repulse.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: —I would fain have the refusal come from him— And yet—

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Nay, my dear Emmeline, start no more objections —I thought I had fully satisfied your scruples, when you satisfied mine. Love knows no bonds, no shackles but what it imposes on itself. It disdains the formal restrictions imposed on it by others, and submits to no obligations but those of the heart.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: [smiling] But is this law, Mr. Witmore.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: The law of love, my dear Emmeline, which is the law of liberty.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: And is there nothing inequitable in the case, eh!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p:
Why to say truth, there is some little difference between law and equity in most cases. But the court of love, my dear Emmeline, is a court of common law, and is governed
by ancient customs and usages time immemorial ; of which none is of longer standing than that of a woman's changing her mind. We shall certainly carry our point, therefore, at law ; which will put me in possession of your charms, and then let equity disposess me of them if it can.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: How lucky it is that I have fallen into the hands of so great a lawyer! [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE I. Sir Solomon Bauble's.
div3.stage: Enter Governor MAMMON and Lady BAUBLE.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: With a due reciprocation of civilities, Sir, I must needs say that your actions bespeak it. There is, indeed, a generosity in your behaviour, that hath charmed us all, except my niece Emmeline. I cannot think what's come to the girl ; but she's grown quite hypocondriac, as I tell her.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Thoughtful, perhaps, on her approaching change of condition, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Or perhaps, Governor, she expected a present, as well as Sir Solomon and myself. We women are all a little mercenary, you know. And besides she might think it a mark of disrespect that she had none. One cannot tell— these young things, who know but a little of the world, have strange conceptions.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: I should be sorry, Madam, that Miss Emmeline's inexperience should cause her to censure me for want of respect ; but I reserved such testimony of my regard for her, till I should have the honour of presenting it myself. This casket of diamonds—

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p:
And have you brought her a casket of diamonds then? Oh she'll brighten up at the diamonds, I'll warrant her. I'll send her to you immediately. —But here she is.
Enter EMILIA. Come, niece Emmeline, here is Governor Mammon, that is to be your husband, you know, [taking hold of her band and leading her toward the Governor, who advances to salute her.] As you must have a great deal to say to one another, I leave you together, Governor, [aside] I long to have their confabulation over, that I may contemplate the beauty of the diamonds. [Exit.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: [bowing as he retires from faluting her.] Miss Emmeline, your slave— [aside] a fine girl grown, faith, [to her.] You will permit me to present you with this token of my respect, before I enter on the subject of my love, [taking a casket out of his pocket and presenting it to her.]

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: [putting aside the casket with her hand.] By no means, Sir. Before I receive any present from you, Governor, it is proper I should know what return I can make you.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: There needs no return, Madam.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: True, Governor, if I become your wife, in which case your present is a mere piece of gallantry : and you may almost as well take it out of one hand and put it into the other. You stile yourself my slave : but rather call me your's; for I am certain you think so.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Miss Emmeline!

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, be not surprized. I am not now, Governor, the poor, simple girl, that was prevailed on to enter into a contract with you in India ; of which I have but lately understood the impropriety.

sp.speaker: G. MAN.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, there seems to be a great alteration, both in your person and sentiments. But as I admire the one, I presume the other will make no alteration in the nature of our connexion.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p:
A groundless hope, Governor. To be plain with you, I find that women educated in England, not only bestow
their persons in marriage ; but that they have minds also, which are interested in the event of that union ; souls, Governor ; of which you Asiatic tyrants will hardly allow us women to boast the possession.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Why really, Miss Emmeline, you seem to be possessed of a soul indeed, if one may judge by this specimen of your spirit. But as the philosophers hold the soul to be of no sex, we Asiatics, as you call us, wisely think the best part of a woman is her person.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: And you would be mean enough to accept the hand of a woman, who had disposed of her heart to another

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Why look ye, madam, if a woman takes upon her to dispose of what is not her property, but has been made over to another, I don't see why the first owner may not, without the imputation of meanness, reclaim it. But is that really the case Miss Emmeline.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: Indeed, governor it is.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Then you have dealt disingenuously by me madam, [putting the casket into his pocket.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: How so, Sir? If all you require of a woman be the possession of her person, what matters it on whom she bestows her affections!

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: I looked on both in you as equally my property.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: Why there, Sir! —it is just as I said—You look upon me as your property, your purchased slave ; and would doubtless treat me as such, were we married. You would be for taking me back to India, to make up the number of your Zenana, your seraglio of female favorites. But that is not in your power, Sir, were I even married to you, without my own consent. And be assured I shall never willingly leave a country in which the privileges of our sex are so well respected and secured. An English wife Governor—

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Is as great a tyrant—

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: As an Eastern husband.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: She may at least set her husband's tyranny at defiance and repay his neglect of her in kind. So beware, Governor, what you do ; and as you approve the hint precipitate our nuptials. [Exit.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Hey day! what a termagant young devil it is grown! Yes, yes, she returned to England, to finish her education with a vengeance! No, no madam, I'll not marry, to go back to India and leave you in England neither. If I do marry you I will certainly get divorced before I go or compell you to go with me. —The privileges of an English wife truly! Repay their neglect in kind! What a poor devil is an English husband!

div3.stage: Enter WITMORE and Serjeant NONPLUS from within.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Governor, your servant.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Well met, Mr. Serjeant—Egad you are luckily encountered here, I must have a little of your advice, or my young Tartar from Bengal will prove too much for me.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: What's the matter, Sir?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: This morning, you know, I consulted you about the shortest method of fulfilling a certain matrimonial contract. And now, I believe, I must consult you on the shortest way of dissolving it.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: So suddenly Sir?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: What on the first interview, Governor?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Why, the yonng lady speaks her mind so plainly, that I've no need of a second.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: She is not to your fancy then Governor?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Or rather I am not to hers. She has taken a fancy to somebody else it seems.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: And did she own it to you?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Yes faith she was explicit enough in all conscience. I cannot complain of her reserve. You must find out some way, therefore, gentlemen to dissolve this same contract.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Impossible, Governor, without fulfilling the condition of the obligation.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: What must I be married to such a shrew against my will?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: O, no, Sir, on the payment of a lack of Rupees you may be excused. These are the terms of the contract, as I take it.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Yes, but, as I take it, that forfeiture is too considerable. I'll marry her tho' it be to have the pleasure of divorcing her the next day.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: True Governor if that pleasure might be so soon had.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: May it not? I understood divorces were now become as frequent in England, as in the East.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: They are pretty frequent indeed, Governor, and when the parties are agreed, are easily brought about. But if either be refractory, they are somewhat dilatory and expensive.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: And pray, Gentlemen, in what time and expence upon an average now, may a man by the laws of England, get rid of a refractory wife.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: By the law of reason and therefore by the laws of England, Sir, it should be very soon.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: But, by the practice of them it cannot be at all.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Even so Sir, a new law must be expressly made for that purpose.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: By that means it may be brought about.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Well, no matter for the means, the time and expence.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Let me fee—The time and expence! — Crim. con. we must take for granted.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Ay, ay, in all appearance we shall want no no proof of that.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: An action may be prosecuted in the Temporal Court a reasonable time and a moderate expence ; brother Witmore.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Yes, yes; we common lawyers have some conscience.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Verdict obtained at Westminster, we go into the commons. A libel is instituted—recrimination ensues—

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Recrimination! What's that? Mr. Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: The recrimination of the canonists, Sir, is the antecatagory of the civilians.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: It is! Oh, ho! that makes every thing very plain.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: You must know, Governor, our canonists maintain that a woman may as lawfully go astray from her husband as a man from his wife.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: The devil!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and our married women of course, play the devil on the authority.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Pope Boniface the 8th, Sir, as the priests had no wives of their own, indulgently promulgated this doctrine, for them to preach to the wives of others.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: But what have we to do with Pope Boniface or his indulgencies?

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: More than you may imagine, Governor. The reformatio legum not taking place the papal cannons continue still in force, and Si quando mulier maritum—but perhaps I had better speak plain English—

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: By all means, Mr. Serjeant, if you can. — As you are upon a matter of importance, I should be glad to understand you.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Then, Sir, to put the case familiarly, thus. If Jack A. being lawfully married to Jill B. peradventure Jill should prove a jade (as, now a days, it is ten to one but she does) yet, nevertheless and notwithstanding, if the said Jill make it appear that the said Jack is as bad as herself ; it is in such case to be adjudged, that the parties Jack and Jill are well matched, and it were a sin to separate so worthy a couple.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Confound the pope and all his adherents!

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: With all my heart Governor ; except out brethren in the commons; with whom to proceed. —

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Ay, ay proceed, proceed Mr. Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Recrimination ended. —Alimony settled. — Term probatory over go to trial. —Cast! no matter which side, the husband pays costs on both.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: The devil! he does!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Ay, Governor, there's the devil again.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p:
An appeal is next lodged in the Arches. — the ground gone over again. —Thence an appeal to the Delegates a definitive sentence is obtained. This being in
your favour, on settling a handsome separate maintenance on your wife you turn her off a mensa et thoro.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: And so get fairly rid of her, ha!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Not so fast, Governor ; only from bed and board.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Besides, Sir, unless you fly the country, your Lady, if she be industrious, may bring you a numerous family of well-begotten children ; to all of which you would be the only lawful father.

sp.speaker: G. MAM,
sp.p: Zounds! Gentlemen can this be law?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Sound law, I assure you, Governor.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Ay, ay, found law! found law! —But, to go on with Our process—

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Oh! confound its prolixity.

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: With sentence for separation a mensa et thoro, Governor, we go next into parliament for a divorce a vinculo matrimonii, the last stage.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Where you may carry your point.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Hell and the devil! what a process!

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: Let me see! Brother Witmore, ay, on a moderate computation, in about ten years and at the expence of twenty, ay twenty, or one and twenty, thousand pounds, the Governor may fairly get rid of his wife—that is, as I said before crim. con. taken for granted.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: So you see, Governor, you may marry her as soon as you please.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: And so I will, though cuckoldom be my portion, if I cannot get rid of her, without suing for a divorce. You may proceed therefore, gentlemen, with the settlements : Yes, I'll marry her and ship her for India immediately, or perhaps ship her first, lest she should give me the slip and run off with her lover. [Exit.

div3.stage: The Lawyers look at each other with confusion.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Ser. NON.
sp.p: How's this brother Witmore? What cause have we been pleading here?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Ship her for India, said he! Egad, we must demur immediately, Mr. Serjeant. It will be too late to bring a writ of error after execution. Let us go to chambers and consult.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: NON. Oh! a demurrer! a demurrer! by all means, Master Witmore, a demurrer. [Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE II. Boothby's Lodgings.
div3.stage: Enter Lady LOVEMORE and Mrs. GOODWILL.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Mrs. Boothby gone abroad, say you!

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: To Pritchards, to give orders for her habit, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Oh! I shall then meet with her ten to one in my round. If not, tell her I shall call to take her with me in the evening. I must run away immediately. [Going out is met by General Gantlet.]

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: [stopping her] Don't put yourself in a fluster, sister. I am sorry for your Ladyship's situation! but these things will happen.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Happen, General! —What will happen!

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Nay, madam, I thought by your flurry you had heard more than I—But if you have heard nothing, and will promise me not to be frightened, I will tell you.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Promise not to be frightened—You have frightened me to death already. But indeed you are always terrifying me with some disaster or other. What's the matter now?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Nay, it may come to nothing, therefore it is time enough to be alarmed—Mrs. Goodwill!

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: What time did Mr. Boothby go out?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: I cannot exactly say the hour, Sir. But it was soon after you left him this morning. Lord Lovemore called in again, and they went out together.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: As I thought. That is two or three hours ago. Mr. Boothby, you find sister, is not returned ; and I am just come from your house, where they know nothing of his Lordship ; so that it is plain one or both of them must have dropped.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Dropped! Lord Lovemore or Mr. Boothby! Heaven and earth! Was there any quarrel between them?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Quarrel, madam! Was it not unavoidable after the affair of last night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: So this rash General has been fomenting mischief and stirring up strife again!

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: And what, brother, had you to do with the affair of last night?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: I will not suffer the honour of my friends, madam, to be hurt by their pusillanimity. And while I have that of being your husband's brother-in-law, he shall neither give nor take an affront, if I can help it, without resenting or being called to account for it.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Your notions of honour, brother, are ridiculous. Is it less dishonourable for a man to cut his friend's throat, than to be civil to his wife?

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: I am an old batchelor, you know, and know nothing about wives. But if Boothby has not cut your husband's throat for the insult offered him at your house laft night, he is a—

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p:
And so you have been setting them to sighting, I find. Oh, I shall faint! I shall die! My poor Lord is certainly
killed! He is murdered. [She throws herself into the chair and affects to faint away.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: [running to her assistance, and taking smelling bottle from her pocket.] Help! help! here. —Pray, General, lay hold of the Lady's hand and keep it open.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Me! not I madam! I know nothing of palmistry.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Bless me, General : how could you go to frighten my Lady in this manner!

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Poh! frightened! If his Lordship be killed, he dies like a man of honour, and she may the sooner get another husband.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: [recovering] Talk not to me brother of another husband! I shall never live to support the loss of this!

div3.stage: Enter BOOTHBY.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Ha! Boothby! [turns on his heel and walks to the back of the stage.]

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Boothby! where—where is my poor Lord? barbarous man! have you indeed then left him dead, or shall I see him again alive? [throwing herself again into the chair.]

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: [aside] So! so! so! Honour and dignity has been making fine work of it here, I find! [to Lady Lovemore] Your poor Lord, madam! I left him rich, alive and well not five minutes ago, turning over the habits at Pritchard's.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Heaven be praised!

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: So say I, my Lady. Let me beg of your Ladyship to compose yourself. You see nothing has happened that should thus distress you.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: [having taken Boothy aside] So, nothing came of it! Ha! —what! disarm'd! —A scratch only, Eh! —Egad I wish I had said nothing about it.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I believe, indeed, it had been better, General.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: [rising from her chair] Inhuman brother! Why! why will you be thus perpetually frightening me? You had better draw your sword and pierce my bosom at once than be thus ever terrifying me with false alarms.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Fire and furies! madam! draw upon a woman! I that have dared death and destruction at the head of a line of battle! What effeminacy have you ever seen in me, madam, to think I should contaminate my sword with the blood of a woman? It is well, madam, it is not your husband that insults me thus. If he had, I would have wrung off his neck, as I would that of a turkey-cock. Draw my sword on a woman! —But 'tis a woman's insult, and so I put up with the indignity. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Bless me, Mr. Boothby, this brother of mine is quite frantic. Is there no method of curing this ridiculous folly.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I am afraid not, madam ; but I'll make a trial. I fancy I could frighten him as much as he has frightened your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Would you could, Captain Boothby ; it would give me great satisfaction and might have some good effect on him ; for really his caprices are dreadful.

div3.stage: Enter SERVANT with a Letter for BOOTHBY.

sp.speaker: SERV.
sp.p: A letter, Sir—the bearer said it required no answer, but must be given into your hands immediately.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Your Ladyship will excuse me.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: No apology Mr. Boothby—business must be minded—I must hurry away to assist Mrs. Boothby in the choice of her dress.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Your Ladyship's humble servant. [Exit Lady LOVEMORE. Now let me see.

To Capt. Boothby —
If Captain Boothby would prevent his wife's ruin and preserve his own honour, he will hinder her going to the masquerade with Lord Lovemore, or when there will most carefully watch the behaviour of his Lordship.

The hand-writing is a woman's, and resembles that of Lady Lovemore ; but it cannot be hers—she is to accompany my wife, and therefore would hardly dissuade me from letting her go. Besides, she seems not to have the least tincture of jealousy in her disposition—Yet now I reflect ; come this notice from whom it will, it may not be proper to neglect it. Mrs. Boothby's conduct is mysterious. Her resentment last night at Lord Lovemore's was unaffected and natural. And, though the passed off the matter slightly to day, the manner in which she did it was neither easy nor natural—There may be something more in this business than I am aware of. I will take Mrs. Boothby to task roundly for her reserve. I'll make her believe I know more than I do, that she may tell me more than I know. — Here she comes. Enter Mrs. BOOTHBY. Come hither madam. I have something to say to you—but first let me shut the door.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Something to say to me! and such preparation, it must be of importance sure, Mr. Boothby.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: It is madam. Tell me, Mrs. Boothby [taking her hastily by the hand] and tell me truly, as you value my future quiet and your own happiness, have you dealt fairly by me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Bless me, Mr. Boothby, what do you mean? You terrify me to death by this earnestness. Dealt fairly by you?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Ay, fairly, Mrs. Boothby.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Witness Heaven! that I have done it ever.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, call not Heaven to witness a falsehood— You have deceived me Mrs. Boothby—You have treacherously concealed from me a secret, which I ought to have known, and which, had I not by other means discovered it, might have proved our ruin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Of what falsehood? What deceit? What treachery have I been guilty?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: You told me to day, that you thought Lord Lovemore meant nothing by the behaviour you resented last night.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Unkind Mr. Boothby! did not you yourself say every thing to persuade me so? Did you not say that gratitude for the obligations his Lordship sought to confer on us, required the most favourable construction to be put on his actions!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Obligations, madam! had he laid obligations on me till he had raised pile to reach the skies, the favour he sought to confer by your means, would have tumbled them all down, and buried them in oblivion. —It is in vain to conceal It any longer. This letter, this letter, madam, has given me damnable intimations of the favours intended us.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: By all my hopes of happiness, both here and hereafter, I declare I have concealed nothing from you, but out of motives of the most sincere fidelity and affectionate tenderness. I knew you to be so jealous of your honour, that I dreaded the fatal consequences of telling you all.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p:
And are not you, madam, equally jealous of my honour, that out of such mistaken tenderness for my personal
safety, you would betray the most invaluable treasure of my soul? I Would you from so weak a motive subject me to be pointed at as the credulous dupe, the easy fool, the wittol of a titled rascal whom I caress as a friend.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Indeed, indeed you wrong me, Mr. Boothby. Heaven forbid I should be put to the trial ; but I think I could. sacrifice every thing I hold most dear to the preservation of your honour.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: As far as it is dependent on your fidelity, you may think it safe. The worst even a bad woman can do is to make herself ridiculous, it is on herself only that she can entail infamy. But men of honour, madam, have a degree of it to maintain, superior to that which is in a woman's keeping.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I will myself, madam, be the guardian both of my own honour and of yours. I have before told you a woman's best confidant is her husband.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Will you then promise to command your temper, and not be urged by that of others to violence.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Then will I positively confide in you ; and should his Lordship make any farther advances, acquaint you with it. And now, my dear, let me know the contents of that letter.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Read it [gives Mrs. Boothby the letter, and looks at her attentively while she reads it]. Well, madam, what think you of it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: I think it is the contrivance of a very artful and a very jealous woman.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: My Lady Lovemore!

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p:
It is her hand—though purposely disguised —I am sure of it. I was before this almost tempted to
think her base enough to countenance the gallantries of her husband.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Impossible! with her you are safe, whatever be the designs of his Lordship.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Then you would have me still go to the masquerade.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: By all means; we cannot with any kind of decency break the appointment without breaking at once with Lord Lovemore ; which neither good manners nor prudence will yet justify.

Mrs. BOOTH. I will then go in to dress. Pritchard has promised to send me the habit, you so much admired to day. [Exit. Manet BOOTHBY. How loose are the principles of men of intrigue! And how often do we attribute, to motives of humanity and generosity, a conduct influenced by the desire of gratifying personal vanity or mere animal appetite. —Lord Lovemore is to sunk in my esteem, that I can place no confidence in his honour. I shall so far take the letter-writer's advice, therefore, as to watch his motions to night very narrowly. Enter Mrs. GOODWILL. Oh! Mrs. Goodwill! if General Gantlet should return I have a little plot upon him, which you must assist me in. Lady Lovemore wishes to be revenged on him for the fright he has just put her in. Now the General was duelling yesterday and wounded his antagonist : the wounds I understand are not dangerous, but it will be easy for us to persuade him that they are mortal.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: An excellent device, if it should but terrify him to run away! His honour and dignity would be finely mortified before he discovered the trick that was put on him.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Egad, here he comes—do you be within hearing, Mrs. Goodwill, and second my attempt as you see necessary.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: You may depend on me, Sir. [Exit.

div3.stage: Re-enter General GANTLET.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: I forgot, Boothby, to ask you if you intend playing the fool at the Hay-market, to night. —I think of going.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Egad, General, I believe you had better think of a prudent expedition to the continent. You acted the part of a man, it seems, so seriously with your antagonist yesterday, that you should be careful how you play the fool to night. I understand he lies at the point of death.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Zounds! The surgeon told me he was in no danger.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Yes, but it seems they have called in another of more dangerous practice, and he declares otherwise. So that if the man dies, General, the lawyers, who know nothing about the point of honour, you know—

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Confound the surgeons and the lawyers too—Die! let him die and be sepulchred on a dunghill.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, but confider, General, I would have you make off by all means, and get out of the kingdom as fast as you can.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Make off! What like a house-breaker or a highwayman! Make off!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Nay, General, don't be angry. —But if you stay, and matters stand as I hear them related, you will run the utmost danger.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: But is it not derogatory to a man's dignity to fly from danger?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: If it threatened only from the point of a bayonet or the mouth of a culverin, I grant you, General. But when it appears in the form of a halter and the gallows.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Egad, you say true, Boothby, there is no dignity in the gallows. I will decamp.

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. GOODWILL in haste.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Bless me, gentlemen, I am almost frightened out of my wits. —Here has been two of Sir John Fielding's people enquiring after General Gantlet : But as I heard of the ugly affair that happened yesterday, I said his honour was not here—The servant says they are still lurking about the street. Therefore pray take care how you go out, General. —What a thing it would be if your honour's dignity should come to be hanged.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: Hell and the devil! what shall I do—Not that I value my life, Capt. Boothby, of a button. I have shewn that at the head of a line of battle : but to be throttled with a halter! the indignity of it, Boothby! I shall die with shame under the indignity of it.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Let me see—What can be done in this emergency? You might escape under disguise ; and that the more readily as it is masquerade night. —But a domino is not sufficient, and I have no other at hand.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: What think you of women's apparel, Sir? I can furnish his honour with a sack and petticoat.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: A petticoat!

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I'll run and fetch it immediately. [Exit.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: A petticoat! I will be taken, hanged, drawn and quartered, e're I put on a petticoat. A soldier, a commander, wear a petticoat!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p:
Pshaw! General, there is nothing in a petticoat, which the bravest man upon earth need he offended at. Achilles, you know, who out-hectored Hector, was glad to conceal himself under one of his mother's maids short petticoats,
Nay, Hercules himself changed his club for a distaff, and threw off his lion's skin, to put on fair Omphale's petticoat.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: By the Lord, you say true : egad, I had forgot it. A man, as you say, may be as valiant as Hercules, and yet be glad sometimes to creep under a petticoat. Where, where is it?

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. GOODWILL with a tête, sack, and petticoat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Here, here, Sir, with a lady's tête too, to complete the disguise.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Ay, this is the very thing, Mrs. Goodwill. [Booth. and Mrs. Good. assist to dress Gant.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: [while, he is dressing] Lookye, Boothby, it is not because I fear to die. —I have shewn that, as I said before, in the field of battle. —Nor that I think I have done wrong in ridding the world of a rascal—I could die with a safe conscience! —But the manner of it, Boothby! —The manner of it! I would avoid the indignity of being carted with street-robbers and footpads, Might I be indulged in the satisfaction of being blown from the mouth of a cannon, or plead privilege to have the honour of being decapitated like a gentleman, may I be crucified if I would budge a foot. — But to be dragged like a calf, with a rope about its neck to the slaughter ; to hear wide-mouthed hawkers cry my last dyingspeech and confession! —Come, come, Mrs. Goodwill, make haste with your petticoat. —Hercules himself wore a petticoat.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: There, Sir, 'twill do very well—Now for your tête.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: An admirable disguise—and well fitted.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: And very becoming too, I protest—Oh! and here, your honour, is your Ladyship's fan. [taking a fan out of her pocket.]

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: Ay, ay, come give me my truncheon. [taking the fan.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD,
sp.p: [aside] Well, if this does not cure him of duelling, he should have a statute of lunacy taken out against him and be shut up in the hospital of incurables. [Exit.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: (after looking at himself for some time.) So! a pretty figure for a General! Eh, Boothby! I would not have you think, my dear boy, that it is out of fear I submit to wear this effeminate disguise ; it is only to avoid suffering an indignity unbecoming a man. Ever while you live, Boothby, preserve the dignity of man!

div3.stage: [Exeunt GAN. fanning himself and holding up his train.

div3.head: SCENE I. Capt. Boothby's Lodgings.
div3.stage: Enter BOOTHBY and WITMORE.

sp.speaker: BOOTH,
sp.p: How! talk of shipping the young lady back to India! He dare not attempt it, sure!

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: It is hard to say what an India Governor, accustomed to the insolence of Asiatic tyranny, may not attempt. His wealth may promise him impunity ; and a step of that kind is easier prevented than amended. I have prevailed on Emilia, therefore, to give her aunt the slip and take refuge with Mrs. Boothby, to night. Tomorrow we shall seek another asylum.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I rejoice at the occasion afforded me of obliging my friend, as I dare say Mrs. Boothby will, at that of assisting my cousin. —Mrs. Goodwill. Enter Mrs. GOODWILL. Please to let Mrs. Boothby know I would speak to her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: She bade me tell you, Sir, she was gone to the masquerade. She said you knew her dress, which might be easily distinguished among the masks.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: This is unlucky. But no matter, you'll bring the lady here, Witmore, Mrs. Goodwill may be trusted, and will attend you till Mrs. Boothby returns.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I shall be obliged to her—You may expect us presently, Mrs. Goodwill. (Exit.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: So, Lady Lovemore has taken Mrs. Boothby to the masquerade, you say, Mrs. Goodwill.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: Oh no, Sir. Lady Lovemore sent to excuse herself : his Lordship also called afterwards, to acquaint Mrs. Boothby that an accident had happened, which prevented her ladyship from stirring out to night.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: And did my wife go with his Lordship?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: No, Sir, but, as he was very pressing for her to do it, she promised to follow him,

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: How! it was highly indiscreet of her. Mrs. Goodwill to go alone. Be so obliging as to fetch my domino and mask down stairs. madam—I must follow her immediately. (Exit Mrs. Goodwill. BOOTHBY alone. I dont half like Lady Lovemore's staying at home and his Lordship's officiousness, in seconding her messages and pressing my wife to accompany him. —And yet there can be no design in it, sure! —My wife refused to go with him. —Yes, but it seem she promised to follow him ; and he knows, to her knowledge too, the habit she was to appear in. —That —That —Zounds! what a tedious while this woman stays! I might almost have been with them by this time. (Exit

div3.head: SCENE II. Sir Solomon Bauble's.
div3.stage: Enter Lady BAUBLE and Mrs. BRUSH.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Gone out at this time of night! Emilia! my niece! Gone out! do you say?

BRUSH. Yes, my lady. She said, because his worship had lost his best Othur yesterday, she would see that the streetdoor was locked to night herself. The Antic-queerians, she said, might run away with her, for ought she knew. I thoft she was coming up stairs immediately ; I thoft no harm.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: And you let her go by herself, you illiterate, careless creature! did you? Some ruffians may have rushed in and carried her off by violence.

sp.speaker: BRUSH.
sp.p: Very likely, my Lady, for I thoft I saw an ill-looking fellow, like a servant out of place, in an old livery, hankering and hankering about the door all the evening.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: And why did not you tell me of it, then, you slut? My niece might be ravished, murdered, married, for ought you cared! Here, where is Sir Solomon? —Run all of you, some one way and some another. Alarm the watch, call up the constable —go dirctly for Governor Mammon — Where, where is Sir Solomon! — [Exeunt Brush, and Servants.

div3.stage: Enter Sir SOLOMON BAUBLE.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Here, here, who calls! I was only just taking leave of my princess before I went to bed, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Out updn your Princess—I wish you was bedded to her with all my heart. —You are a pretty guardian truly to take more care of a mummy than of your ward.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: My ward! why what's the matter, wise?

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Matter enough Sir, somebody has carried off your niece.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: How! carried off Emilia! Run away with her by force?

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Nay, I know not that : she may have followed the example of your daughter for ought I know. The collateral branches of the family may possibly take after one another, tho' they diverge in the descending line. —I wonder your masculine sagacity, Sir Solomon, did not foresee this disaster.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: I don't wonder that your feminine foresight did not prevent it! Woman's wit! quotha! —But who went with her! —Which way went she? —

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Nay, if we knew that, we might know which way to go after her.

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. BRUSH and a WATCHMAN.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Well. Watchman, did you see any thing of a young Lady, who looked as if the was running away with herself?

sp.speaker: WAT.
sp.p: Your worship's kinswoman, Sir, Madam Emily, I think they call her, passed by my stand just now.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Any body with her?

sp.speaker: WAT.
sp.p: A young gentleman, as my partner says, belonging to the Temple : He knows them, for my part I does not know neither him nor she.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: A templar! eh! a sad dog, I'll warrant him, my lady.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Oh, a pretty rake! no doubt.

sp.speaker: WAT.
sp.p: For my part, I took her for a crack ; as the gentleman called a coach off the stand and bid him drive toward Covent Garden.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Run, fly, Mr. Watchman, pursue the coach. Go, fellow, run. [Exit. Enter

div3.stage: Enter THOMAS.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Well, Sir, where have you been?

sp.speaker: THO.
sp.p: After my young mistress, Sir, —And I came back to tell you that the coach drove so consounded fast that I could not overtake it.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Why did you not run faster then, blockhead?

sp.speaker: THO.
sp.p: I did Sir. And yet, for all that, had it not stopped when it did, I should have never have come up with it.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Then it did stop, and you did come up with it. Eh!

sp.speaker: THO.
sp.p: Yes, my lady, at the door of a habit shop in Tavistock Street. I suppose the gentleman and miss are going to the masquerade. So I thought that, while they were putting on their dresses, I would just step back, to let your Ladyship and his Worship know where to find them.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Well done Thomas. Yes, yes I'll be with them presently. Give me my roccelo and bid somebody run and call a coach.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: And me a chair. I'll slip on my things and go with you. Come Brush get me any bonnet and cloak. [Exit.

div3.stage: THOMAS re-enters with Sir SOLOMON's Roccelo, Hat ana Cane.

sp.p: Sir SOL. And do you hear, Thomas—run you to Governor Mammon and bring him after us immediately. —I'll deliver my niece into his hands this very night, I protest. You have done well Thomas—Bring Governor Mammon with you immediately. And, do you hear, Thomas for fear we should want assistance, tell his Banyan to muster up his attendants; from his Dallals and Darògas, down to his honour's Pykes, Peons and Cooleys. Do you hear Thomas!

sp.speaker: THO.
sp.p: I will Sir. Exeunt.

div3.head: SCENE III. Boothby's Lodgings.
div3.stage: Enter WITMORE, and EMILIA followed by Mr. GOODWILL.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Don't be flurried, my dear Emilia, we are arrived safe.

sp.speaker: EM.
sp.p: I am so frightened, lest they should have followed and watched us in.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Don't be apprehensive, my dear girl. —As we left the coach at the door of the habit-shop, and you came away masked in a chair, we have certainly eluded the vigilance of our pursuers, if there were any.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p:
This way Madam if you please. This way, Sir, be under no apprehensions of surprize : The servants will let no stranger in without giving me notice. Exeunt. Enter BOOTHBY. Curse on my foolish curiosity! How miserable it has made me! I did not think I could have been so suddenly jealous. My wife Cannot sure encourage Lord Lnvemore! And yet, as I watched them about the rooms, I surprized her in such familiar conversation with him. She did not speak loud enough for me to hear what she said, indeed ; but she seemed to whisper so frequently ; and her signs were so significantly encouraging, her attitudes so provokingly inviting, that I was several times in the mind to pluck the mask from her face and expose her, him and myself, to the Company.—I did not imagine she could so readily have entered into the spirit of the place. — —Who knows, in her gaité de coeur, how far things may be carried!
They may have left the rooms for greater freedom of conversation elsewhere. —Confound the crowd in which I lost fight of them. [Going ; Stops short. Ha! here they are! —Bring him home to her own lodgings! Is this simplicity or art! —I fear I have been made their dupe. —But I'll see a little more. [Retires behind the Scene.

div3.stage: Enter Lord LOVEMORE in a domino, with a mask in his hand, leading a Lady in a fancy dress, masked.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Nay, my dear Mrs. Boothby, why carry on the farce now?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: [aside] My dear Mrs. Boothby! Yes, yes, I am now convinced. —It is clear they have made a dupe of me.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Not one word! Have you so kindly invited me home not to speak to me? Will not your tongue confirm my happiness? By this hand I will force the seal of silence from those charming lips with kisses. [offers to kiss the Lady.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: By this band, my Lord, but you shall not. [Laying hold of Lard Lovemore's arm.

sp.speaker: LADY.
sp.p: Oh! [screams and runs off.]

div3.stage: [After sometime looking at each other.]

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Capt. Boothby!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p:
Lord Loveinore! —Your Lordship has some grace left I see by your confusion. And so my dear Mrs. Boothby has kindly invited you home, and after all won't speak to yeu. —I will lay my commands on her, my Lord, she shall speak to you. —Come forth, Mrs. Boothby ; come forth and speak to Lord Lovemore ; his Lordship is impatient to hear the confirmation of his happiness from those charming lips. [Going up to door finds it locked. Ha! locked! —Open the door this instant, madam, or, by
heavens I'll split it into a thousand pieces, Provoke not the rage of an injured husband, left he should be no longer able to restrain it.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: On my honour, Mr. Boothby, no injury hath been done you.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Perhaps less than was intended, my Lord : but I am convinced it was not your fault that an irreparable injury is not done me. I am not so credulous, therefore, as to take your Lordship's word. Your honour, my Lord, is a bad security for your veracity. We must hear what Mrs. Boothby says to it. Come forth, I say, Madam — Mrs. Boothby!

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. BOOTHBY with, Mrs. GOODWILL, from another part of the scene.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Who calls me so loudly? —Mr. Boothby! [Lord Lovemore and Capt. Boothby look with surprize at each other.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: So soon undressed, madam! This is masquerading indeed! Did not you go into this room just now, in the habit, I saw you dressed in to night at the Haymarket?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: You forgot, my dear, that there is no other door to that room. Nor did you see me to night dressed in any habit at the Haymarket.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: How! madam! Would you persuade me I did not know you? Did not you, Mrs. Goodwill, say my wife was gone to the masquerade?

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: I said, Sir, your Lady bade me tell you so.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: No prevaricating, no shuffling madam! I say, my wife was to night at the masquerde.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p:
And I can answer for Ms. Boothby, Sir, that she has not been out of doors to night. —She has been
conversing for some time with the gentleman and lady, you ecpected ; who are now above stairs.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Mr. Witmore and Emilia!

sp.speaker: Ms. BOOTH.
sp.p: It is even so, my dear. Being disappointed of my habit, I sent to acquaint Lady Lovemore of it. who returned me word that an unforeseen accident likewise prevented her Ladyship's going. Indeed my Lord came afterwards to apologize for her, and pressed me so hard to accompany him, that, in order to get rid of his importunity, I was in a manner obliged to promise I would follow him : so that Mrs. Goodwill told you no untruth.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: But why impose on me by equivocation?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: That I mightoot deprive yoo of an amusement, my dear, merely because I could not partake of it myself, I thought you would return when you did not find me among the masks.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I thought I had found you, madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: In the person, I suppose, to whom my habit was sent by mistake. You have no reason, I hope, to be much displeased at your disappointment.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: As you were prudent enough to disappoint his Lordship, I am satisfied.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: That is more than I am. —As Lady Love-more is at home, and Mrs. Boothby has not been abroad all the evening, you will give me leave to see who is in this room.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Force open the door, then, my Lord, you conducted hither the Lady who went into it.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: That I will, without ceremony. [Rushes agaist the door, forces it open and goes in.

sp.speaker: Mrs. GOOD.
sp.p: (aside) What violence is this?

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: What is all this, Mr. Boothby?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p:
We shall see presently, my dear. As yet I hardly know myself. Some demirp, I supoose, has been
quetting with Lord Lovemore : but his reason for bringing her hither is somewhat particular.

div3.stage: Re-enter Lord LOVEMORE leading in the Lady, still masked.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Come, madam, will you be pleased to unmask, that I may know to whom I am obliged for so many civilities? [The Lady unmasks. ALL but Lord Lovemore. Lady Lovemore! Ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! —have I been all this while making love to my own wife? —What a contemptible figure do I make here!

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Come, come, my Lord, don't babashed. If you can be but half so gallant at home as I find you can be abroad, you may yet have no reason to repent it.

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: You, madam, may have reason though to repent of this fine foolery.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: I shall never repent, my Lord, of preventing you doing what you yourself would have-much more reason to repent of. —Mrs. Boothby, I hope, will excuse my personating her on this occasion, as well as the artifices I made use of, to procure her habit and detain her at home.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: Your Ladyship need not apologize to me for any thing that is past.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: And what says Lord Lovemore to what has past?

sp.speaker: Lord LOVE.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir. I am neither disposed to ask pardon nor bear reproof. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Lady LOVE.
sp.p: Well said, Lord Lovemore! Carry it off like yourself. But I must have some talk with you on this business; and that immediately too. [Exit.

div3.stage: Enter Sir SOLOMON and LADY BAUBLE.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Ay, ay, this is the house, this is the house, my Lady. —Let the constables wait without.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: What's this? Sir Solomon! my father in law!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: I disclaim you, Sir. —Where is my niece Emmiline? What! would not the robbing me of a daughter content you, but you must likewise seduce my ward?

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: And you, my pretty sormal, sugitive daughter, was it not enough that you had ruined yourself, but you must assist in the ruin of your run-away cousin too? —Where is she?

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Ay, where is she! Let her appear this moment, or we'll call in the constables and break open the doors. She was seen to come in here.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Ay, ay, call in the constables, Sir Solomon ; and let them break open the doors.

div3.stage: A noise is heard without. Enter a CONSTABLE.

sp.speaker: CONST.
sp.p: [coming in] Stand aside, stand aside there ; the young lady is found ; let her come in.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: How! I thought they said she was already in the house.

sp.speaker: CONST.
sp.p: No! no! Sir! We stopped her, an' please your worship, as she was coming out of a chair to get into a postchaise, to set off for France. Had not she seemed shy of being seen, we should not have suspected her. She's very obstropulous for a young lady! she won't let us see her face—so that we are sure it must be she. —Let the lady come in, there.

div3.stage: Enter GENERAL GANTLET still in woman's cloaths.

sp.speaker: CONST.
sp.p: Come miss—you'll let these gentlesolks see your face, I suppose.

sp.speaker: GAN.
sp.p: [aside] Zounds! What a congregation are got together here!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: [aside] The General! What a whimsical incident! I must save his dignity farther mortification, or we shall have him quite outrageous.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Emily! that—that—Emily!

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: What a metamorphosis! I protest, she is so transformed, Sir Solomon, that I should not have known her. Come, madam, pray unmask, and let us see the natural features of that bold face of thine [going up to the General, to pull off his mask].

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Hold, madam! my apartments are the young lady's protection. I receive company on all these public nights and nobody mult be unmasked here against their will. [Turning to the General] This way, madam, if you please : Mrs. Goodwill, be so good as to shew the lady up to the drawing room [Boothby leads General Gantlet across the siage, and beckons to Mrs. Goodwill who goes off with him].

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Don't tell me [running up and snatching off Gantlet's mask, as Mrs. Goodwill leads him off]. Oh!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: What's the matter, my Lady? What, frightened at your niece!

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: No, no, that hard-featured thing is more likely to be her gallant.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Her gallant! What in petticoats! Fine doings these!

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Yes, yes, your niece is got into fine company here—but if I don't rout them—Here, where's the constable.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Hold, madam. Your Ladyship must excuse me, if I prevent you from exposing yourself here.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: How Sir! will you detain a ward from her guardian?

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Oh! here comes the Governor. We shall hear what he says to it.

div3.stage: Enter Governor MAMMON followed by THOMAS.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Wait without there.

Sir SOL. 'Tis well you are come, Governor—Egad, you had like to have been a wife out of pocket, I can tell you. — Mr. Constable look well to the doors—Thomas, see that nobody ships out. [Exeunt THOMAS and CONSTABLE.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Is the young lady overtaken then, Sir Solomon?

sp.speaker: Sir. SOL.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we have housed her. She's safe enough above stairs, if we can but prevail on this gentleman to part with her. Though he cares not for the authority of fathers or guardians, he may respect perhaps the prerogatives and privileges of a husband!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: A husband, Sir Solomon I Is your niece then the gentleman's wife?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: She must be, Sir, if I'm disposed to marry her.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Perhaps not, Sir, if she is not so already : but here she comes.

div3.stage: Enter Mr. WITMORE and EMILIA.

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Another metamorphosis! So, madam, you thought your shallow cunning could outwit your uncle's and my profound sagacity, did you?

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: [to Wit.] How, Mr. Witmore! Is it you that are my rival?

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: The young lady, Governor, hath preferred me to be her guardian ; and no violence must be offered her inclinations.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Nor shall there, Barrister, on my account, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: I have this afternoon, Sir Solomon, been informed by a relation, whom I advised of my arrival, that this young Barrister is my nephew.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: How! the Governor your uncle! and you so undutiful at not to know any thing about him!

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: His ignorance of me is excuseable, Sir Solomon : It is long since I corresponded with the family. —He may possibly have heard of me, but there have been so many Mammons of late years imported from India, that, had the name implied affinity, he might have expected a cargo of cousins by every fleet. But know me now, young gentleman, for your uncle [embracing him.]

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Well, but what is to become of our niece!

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: Why, give her to my kinsman, Madam. I really think the young lady hath provided better for herself than her friends had provided for her.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: And do you resign her to him, Governor?

sp.speaker: G. MAM,
sp.p: Why, look ye, Sir Solomon, I did not chuse to forfeit my lack of Rupees; but as the money will not now go out of the family, I can refign the lady without reluctance. So that, if you consent to their marriage, the young folks shall not be disappointed.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Well, what say you to the proposal, my lady?

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Say! Sir Solomon! What is there to be said? Governor Mammon having a right to claim Emilia for himself, he has a fortiori, as the Logicians say, a right to dispose of her to his Nephew.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Well then, Barrister, with the Governor's leave, I don't say take her ; but, as you have got, you may keep her.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir Solomon. —But to you, Sir, [Speaking to Governor Mammon.] I know not how to make my acknowledgements.

sp.speaker: G. MAM.
sp.p: When we are better acquainted, Nephew, you may learn.

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Ay, ay—and, as you have got so good an Uncle and a wife into the bargain, Barrister, you ought to be satisfied.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Not quite, Sir. You will give me leave to hope you will extend your goodness also to my friend Boothby and your daughter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. BOOTH.
sp.p: May I hope for so great a blessing as your pardon, madam? [To Lady Bauble.]

sp.speaker: Lady BAU.
sp.p: Sir Solomon!

sp.speaker: Sir SOL.
sp.p: Nay, if it rests with me—there—there, take both our blessings between you. It is all I can spru at present, tho'; take that with you.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: I hope otherwise, Sir.

sp.speaker: WIT.
sp.p: Never fear, Boothby ; when favour once comes, fortune will soon follow.

div3.stage: Enter General GANTLET in his own cloathes.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: By heavens, this is not to be put up with. Bedizen'd like a strumpet, dogg'd by thief-takers, dragged along like a street-walker! —Capt. Boothby, I must have satisfaction for all this ; I understand it was a plot of yours and my lady sister's, to expose me. As to her, she is a woman, and I'll have nothing more to do with petticoats.

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: Faith, General, I ask your pardon with all my heart. But I acted in concert with Lady Lovemore merely to set this savage custom of duelling, you are so absurdly fond of, in a ridiculous light.

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: Yes, faith, I feel myself ridiculous enough in all conscience. But my dignity, Boothby!

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p:
How, General! Doth dignity consist in the brutal custom of cutting throats, like cannibals, in cold
blood ? Did the heroes of antiquity want dignity? Yet did Caesar ever send a challenge to Cato, or Cato to Caesar?

sp.speaker: G. GAN.
sp.p: Caesar and Cato, Boothby, were clever fellows, in their day, no doubt. Yes, your Caesars and Catos must have been fine fellows in there time. But sword and pistol were not then in vogue, and the fighting one's friends was not come in fashion. You may call me absurd, if you will ; but how is a man of honour at present to support his consequence without having recourse to the Duel ?

sp.speaker: BOOTH.
sp.p: By having recourse to his good-nature, my dear General : Believe me, there is often more fortitude in forgiving an injury than in revenging it ; and always more dignity in despising insults than in resenting them.

div1.head: EPILOGUE.
div1.p: And spoken by Miss BARSANTI.

sp.l: WELL, men of valour! how do ye like our play?
Nothing against it, sure, the Ladies say! —
To own they're pleas'd the critics ever loth,
May cry "A Duellist with scarce an oath!
"'Tis like his hat, that was without a feather. —
"Duels and dammes, always go together."
Old sinners, loving the licentious joke,
May think there wants too here and there a stroke ;
Round oaths and double meanings, strew'd between,
With them the virtues of the comic scene.
And yet the Town in general is so nice,
It holds these virtues as a kind of vice.
From the teeth outwards chaste, their hands before 'em,
Like reps, ev'n demireps are all decorum.
Though gross their thoughts, so delicate their hearing,
They think the very stage should fine for swearing.
Our author, therefore, scrupled to employ
Your vulgar damme Sir, and damme boy;
Nay, when by chance a naughty joke came pat in,
He wrapt it up, you know, in lawyer's Latin Alluding to a passage in the play, which the Author, in deference to the delicacy of certain Ladies, who understand Latin, has omitted..
So much refin'd the scene since former days,
When Congreve, Vanbrugh, Wycherly wrote plays,
"The stage so loosely did Astrea tread,
"She fairly put all characters to bed ;
Tho' now no bard would venture to deposit
A Macaroni in a lady's closet ;
Lest the frail fair one he be thought to ruin,
While moon and stars alone—see what they're doing.
In the old plays, gallants take no denial,
But put the struggling actress to the trial.
B1ess me! I shudder ev'n now to think
How near ev'n I may stand on dangers brink.
In modern plays, more safe the female station ;
Secure as sad our solemn situation!
No rakish, forward spark dares now be rude :
The Comic Muse herself grown quite a prude!
No wonder then, if, in so pure an age,
No Congreves write for as demure a stage.
